questions.solution:

In Cremasteric reflex, stroking skin at upper and inner thigh, causes upward movement of testis.

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.text: What causes the absolute refractory period?
questions.solution:
Absolute refractory period is due to closure of inactive gates of sodium channel. Absolute Refractory Period: The Na channels quickly switch from their open state to a closed state known as the inactivated state, where they stay for a brief period of time before returning to their resting state where they can once more be activated. This period starts from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete.

Na channel has got 2 gates- outer m gate (activation gate) and inner h gate (inactivation gate). After the spike potential and when repolarisation begins the h gates close and never allow further sodium entry, depolarisation- This period in the early repolarisation is called the absolute refractory period. During the late repolarisation m gate start to close while the h gates starts opening, so sufficient stimulus can push sodium inside and cause depolarisation- this phase is known as Relative refractory period. 



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 88

questions.text: What happens to blood flow if the blood vessel's radius is expanded by 50%?
questions.solution:
Blood flow through a vessel follows Poiseuille's law, which states that blood flow (Q) is directly proportional to the fourth power of the vessel's radius (r ‚Å¥):
Q∝r4

If initial radius is R, and now radius is increased by 50%, the new radius is 1.5R. 
Hence blood flow will increase by (1.5)^4 = 1.5 X 1.5 X 1.5 X1.5 = 5.06X ~ 5X.  Thus, blood flow increases approximately 5 times.

The correct answer is 5 times.

questions.text: 10 mEq/mmol of potassium is present extracellularly while 100 mEq/mmol is present intracellularly. According to the Nernst equation, what will be the equilibrium potential for potassium?
questions.solution:
The membrane potential at which ion influx and outflow are in equilibrium is known as the equilibrium potential.
The potential of an ion with charge z across a membrane can be calculated using the Nernst equation
The concentration of the ion both within and outside the cell is used to calculate this potential:


 
  • E= The membrane potential
  • [C]o - ion outside the cell = The extracellular concentration of that ion= 10 
  • [C]i - ion inside the cell= The intracellular concentration of that ion= 100
  • Z= Va (Valence of K+)
The membrane potential must match the Nernst potential when the membrane is at thermodynamic equilibrium (i.e., there is no net ion flux).

Inputting the values 

Membrane potential = 61/ 1(valence) X log10 (10/100)
= 61 X [1-2]. (since log a/b = log a - log b, log 10 is 1, log 100 is 2)
= 61x -1 = -61mV ~ -60mV

questions.text: What does fluorescence mean?
questions.solution:
In fluorescence, a photon of high energy (shorter wavelength) light is absorbed by an atom or molecule, causing the elevation of an electron to a higher energy state. As the electron relaxes back to its original energy state, it emits a photon of lower energy (longer wavelength) light. This process of absorption and subsequent re-emission of a longer wavelength of light is known as fluorescence.


Reference: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fluorescence

questions.text: In Lewis Triple Response, what causes skin to turn red when scratched with a pointed object?
questions.solution:
Histamine realeased from damaged local mast cells causes redness.
Lewis triple response is a three-part response by the body to blunt injury. It includes an immediate vascular response, an inflammatory response, and a repair response.

The immediate vascular response involves constriction of blood vessels to stop any further bleeding, followed by vasodilation to increase the damage area’s circulation.

The inflammatory response involves recruiting macrophages, neutrophils, and other immune cells to the site of injury, along with elevated levels of inflammatory biomarkers such as histamine leading to redness, prostaglandins, and cytokines. This response helps reduce swelling and prevent any further damage.

The repair response occurs after the initial damage has been contained by the above responses, and includes building new tissues, such as collagen, to restore the area back to its normal functioning. This response is dependent on proper nutrition in order to ensure that the area is healing.

questions.text: When rising from a seated position, a person's blood pressure drops by 10 mm Hg. After correction, the baroreceptor increases the blood pressure by 8 mm Hg with a 2 mm Hg mistake. What benefit does the system provide?

Gain= Correction/Error 

Correction = 8 mm Hg

Persisting error after correction = 10-8 = 2 mm Hg

Hence, Gain = 8/2 = 4.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about excitation-contraction coupling?
questions.solution:
Calcium binds to Troponin C, not to the tropomyosin, to initiate muscle contraction. This binding exposes the Actin binding sites present on the myosin band which were earlier guarded by the tropomyosin helix. E-C coupling proceeds as follows: The membrane potential of a skeletal muscle cell is depolarised by an action potential (e.g. from synaptic activation from an alpha motor neuron) This depolarisation activates voltage-gated DHPRS This activates RyR type 1 via physical linkage As the RyRs open, calcium is released from the SR into the local junctional space, which then diffuses into the bulk cytoplasm to cause a calcium transient. . The calcium released into the cytosol binds to Troponin C by the actin filaments, to allow cross-bridge cycling, producing force and, in some situations, motion. The sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium-ATPase (SERCA) actively pumps calcium back into the SR. As calcium declines back to resting levels, the force declines and relaxation occurs.

questions.text: Which of these inhibits the release of synaptic vesicle from the presynaptic terminal?
questions.solution:
Release of the synaptic vesicle from the presynaptic terminal is inhibited by prevention of calcium influx.

When calcium ions (Ca2+) enter the presynaptic terminal through voltage-gated calcium channels, they bind to several proteins involved in a synaptic vesicle (SV) exocytosis such as SNARE proteins and synaptotagmins.

This triggers a conformational change in the proteins, resulting in the release of neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft.


If the calcium ions are prevented from entering the presynaptic terminal, the proteins involved will not undergo their conformational changes and exocytosis will be inhibited.

questions.text: What does Fick's law (Flick's law was given in the paper) deal with?
questions.solution:
Fick's Law deals with the Passive diffusion of molecules along the concentration gradient.

It states that particles of a substance in a solvent move randomly and are more likely to move from areas of high concentration to those of low concentration, resulting in a net movement of particles.

This reaction occurs over a period of time proportional to the square of the diffusion distance.

The speed of diffusion is dependent on the concentration gradient between two areas and the area of contact

questions.text: Three ions—X, Y, and Z—are freely permeable through a cell's cellular membranes. The equilibrium potentials of X and Y are, respectively, -30 mV and -40 mV at resting membrane potential. If a medication that can block Z's permeability is infused, what will happen to the membrane potential?
questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential (RMP) is determined by ionic gradients and permeability of the membrane to ions of different valence. RMP is closest to the equilibrium potential of the ion with maximum permeability, calculated as the sum of the individual permeabilities and reversal potentials of each ion - X, Y, Z - divided by the sum of the individual permeabilities. Blocking ion channels of Z will shift the RMP closer to the reversal potentials of X or Y based on the relative permeability between them. If Z has a reversal potential or original RMP is more negative, closure of its channels will shift the RMP closer to the reversal potentials of X or Y, thus depolarizing the cell.

questions.text:
Select the accurate statement regarding the image given below:


A: Preload                                            B:Afterload
questions.solution:
A - Preload B - Afterload. Preload and afterload are two conditions that affect the force production and work done by a muscle. Preload occurs when the muscle is passively stretched by the load in its relaxed state, leading to an increased overlap of thin and thick filaments in the sarcomere and increased active tension. Afterload occurs when the load acts only on the muscle while it is in active contraction and is supported during relaxed state. Work done is higher during afterload, as displacement is higher and the load is acting on the muscle more forcefully.

questions.text: What amongst the following treatment shouldn't be used when a person starts feeling breathlessness at a high altitude of 3000 m
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is of Mountain Sickness. When a person starts feeling breathlessness at a high altitude of 3000 m, the most appropriate treatment would be to initiate immediate descent to a lower altitude. Oxygen supplementation (option 2) can be used to treat altitude sickness and improve oxygenation. Acetazolamide (option 4) can be used for the prevention and treatment of altitude sickness. Acetazolamide works by promoting respiratory alkalosis, which can lead to increased ventilation and oxygenation.

 I/V digoxin (option 1) is not indicated for the treatment of altitude sickness and may cause adverse effects such as arrhythmias and cardiac toxicity. Hence  IV digoxin should not be used in this given scenario.

choices.text: Flow of local current in retrograde direction

questions.text: Action potential propagation in neurons is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Sideway movement of Na+ intracellularly
 
  • The nerve cell membrane is polarized at rest, with positive charges lined up along the outside of the membrane and negative charges along the inside.
  • During the action potential, this polarity is abolished and for a brief period is actually reversed.
  • Voltage-gated Na+ channels are highly concentrated in the nodes of Ranvier and the initial segment in myelinated neurons. depolarization in myelinated axons travels from one node of Ranvier to the next. This “jumping” of depolarization from node to node is called saltatory conduction
  • In the natural situation, impulses pass in one direction only, from synaptic junctions or receptors along axons to their termination. Such conduction is called orthodromic. Conduction in the opposite direction is called antidromic. Because synapses permit conduction in one direction only, an antidromic impulse will fail to pass the first synapse they encounter and die out at that point.
  • Calcium ions (Ca2+) also play a role in neuronal signaling, but they are primarily involved in other processes such as neurotransmitter release and synaptic transmission. While Ca2+ does not directly contribute to action potential propagation, it is important for synaptic activity and the modulation of neuronal function.
  • Thus out of the given options, Sideways movement of intracellular sodium propagates AP seems to be the correct option.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 87,88

choices.text: Threshold for stimulation of the proximal part of the neuron is high

questions.text: Why is the conduction of nerve impulse at the synapse unidirectional?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2

Dendrites and body have no neurotransmitter hence at synapse nerve impulse transmission is unidirectional.
Option 4:- Na+ channels can open in only one direction only is the explanation for nerve impulse conduction being unidirectional. 

The unidirectional conduction in a chemical synapse is achieved through several mechanisms:

  • Presynaptic Neuron: This is the neuron that sends the signal. When an action potential (nerve impulse) reaches the axon terminal of the presynaptic neuron, it triggers the release of neurotransmitter molecules from synaptic vesicles into the synaptic cleft.

  • Synaptic Cleft: This is the tiny gap between the axon terminal of the presynaptic neuron and the dendrite or cell body of the postsynaptic neuron.

  • Postsynaptic Neuron: This is the neuron that receives the signal. The neurotransmitter molecules released into the synaptic cleft bind to specific receptors on the membrane of the postsynaptic neuron.

  • Ion Channels and Depolarization: When neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the postsynaptic neuron, they can cause ion channels to open, allowing ions (such as sodium or potassium) to flow into or out of the postsynaptic neuron. This generates a postsynaptic potential, which can either be excitatory (depolarizing) or inhibitory (hyperpolarizing), depending on the type of neurotransmitter and receptor involved.




 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 122

questions.text: Which of the following concerning sarcomere arrangements is correct?
questions.solution:
The sarcomere is the basic unit of muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle. It is composed of thin and thick filaments arranged in a specific pattern.
The correct option is 1, which states that the Z line is present in the middle of the I band.
The A band is the dark band seen in the center of the sarcomere and contains both thick and thin filaments overlapping each other.
The H zone is present in the middle of the A band and contains only thick filaments.
The I band is the light band seen on either side of the A band and contains only thin filaments but not the full length, it also extends in the A band.
The Z line is present in the middle of the I band and represents the boundary between adjacent sarcomeres. The M line is present in the middle of the A band and represents the center of the thick filament.
Therefore, option 1 is correct as it accurately describes the arrangement of the sarcomere.

THE FOLLOWING MECHANISMS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR AN ACTION POTENTIAL :-
  • RESTING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL – Membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage gated Na+ & K+ channels are closed.
  • MEMBRANE DEPOLARISATION – Na+ flows INWARDS.
  • MEMBRANE REPOLARISATION –Na+ inflow STOPS. K+ flows OUTWARDS
  • MEMBRANE HYPERPOLARISATION -K+ gates are slow to close à Excess K+ EFFLUX occurs resulting in a period of HYPERPOLARISATION. Voltage gated Na+ channels go back to resting state. Sodium potassium pump restores the concentration of different ions.

choices.text: Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and phosphate

questions.text: What causes the detachment of the myosin head from the actin active site during muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
• The detachment of the myosin head from the actin active site during muscle contraction is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head.
  • During muscle contraction, the myosin head binds to the actin active site to form a cross-bridge. This cross-bridge is responsible for generating force and movement. When ATP binds to the myosin head, it causes a conformational change that weakens the bond between the myosin head and the actin active site. This leads to the detachment of the myosin head from the actin active site, breaking the cross-bridge.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is option (1) Binding of ATP. The hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and phosphate (option 2) and power stroke (option 4) are involved in the subsequent steps of muscle contraction, while a decrease in sarcoplasmic calcium (option 3) would actually prevent muscle contraction from occurring.
 

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 103,104,105 .

questions.text: 2 blood vessels A and B have laminar blood follow. If the diameter and length of vessel B are double that of vessel A as shown below, flow in B will be how many times the flow in A?
questions.solution:
The volume flow rate is
1. Directly proportional to the 4th power of radius and
2. Inversely proportional to the length
 

The volume flow rate is given by Poiseuille's equation which is as follows:

Q = (π * ΔP * r^4) / (8 * η * L)

Where:
1. Q is the flow rate of the fluid,
2. ΔP is the pressure difference across the pipe,
3. r is the radius of the pipe,
4. η is the viscosity of the fluid, and
5. L is the length of the pipe.

The volume flow rate is therefore 
1. Directly proportional to the 4th power of radius and
2. Inversely proportional to the length

If diameter/radius is increased twice  - flow would become 2*2*2*2= 16 times. 
But since length too is increased twice - the actual flow rate would be = 16/2 = 8 times.
Therefore in this case the flow would be 8 times higher.

 

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 563 .

questions.text:
The conductance of 2 ions in different colors during different phases of the action potential(in red) is shown below. Which of the following pair of ions corresponds to Blue and Green respectively? 

1. Na+ , Ca2+ 
2. Na+, K+
3. K+, Ca2+
4. Ca2+, Na+
questions.solution:
Action potentials are produced by a series of all-or-none changes in ion permeability brought on by the activity of voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels. Blue corresponds to Na+ conductance driving the depolarisation phase of action potential and green corresponds to K+ conductance driving the repolarisation. 
 

During the different phases of the action potential, there are changes in the permeability of ions, specifically sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+). Here is a summary of Na+ and K+ conductance during each phase:

  1. Resting Phase: The resting phase of the action potential is characterized by a relatively stable membrane potential. At this stage, the Na+ channels are closed, and the K+ channels are mostly closed, resulting in low conductance for both ions.

  2. Depolarization Phase: During the depolarization phase, the membrane potential rapidly becomes more positive. This is primarily due to an increase in Na+ conductance. The opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels allows a rapid influx of Na+ ions into the cell, leading to depolarization.

  3. Repolarization Phase: In the repolarization phase, the membrane potential returns to its resting state. This is primarily driven by an increase in K+ conductance. The opening of voltage-gated K+ channels allows K+ ions to move out of the cell, repolarizing the membrane and restoring the resting potential.

  4. Hyperpolarization Phase: After repolarization, the membrane potential briefly becomes more negative than the resting potential. This is known as the hyperpolarization phase. During this phase, K+ conductance remains relatively high, contributing to hyperpolarization.




     

    Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 88,89 .

questions.text: Which among the following statement is true regarding autophagy?
questions.solution:
• The true statement regarding autophagy is: 4. It fuses with a lysosome to form an autophagolysosome.
  • Degradation of worn, aberrant, or defective cellular components occurs within organelles called lysosomes and is referred to as autophagy, also known as autophagocytosis. 
  • During autophagy, a double-membrane structure called the autophagosome forms around the targeted cellular material, such as damaged organelles or proteins.
  • The autophagosome then fuses with a lysosome, forming an autophagolysosome. Inside the autophagolysosome, the targeted material is degraded by lysosomal enzymes, and the resulting molecules are recycled for cellular use.
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 42,44,45,46,47,48 .

questions.text: In hot summers, a farmer while working in the field collapsed. Vitals are noted as: Temperature: 104°F; Pulse Rate – 110 BPM. Which of the following is least likely to occur in this case?
questions.solution:
Given the history, this is most likely a case of heat stroke. Patients with heat stroke don't sweat leading to high temperatures.

  • Heat stroke is considered a medical emergency and leads to many indices of homeostatic imbalance: tachycardia, rapid shallow breathing, dizziness, anhidrosis i.e. a lack of sweating, dry and hot skin, muscle cramping, confusion, and seizures.
  • The clinical manifestations of heatstroke reflect a total loss of thermoregulatory function.
  • Typical vital-sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure. Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, the historical and physical triad of exposure to a heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and a core temperature >40.5°C helps establish the preliminary diagnosis

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3637.

questions.text: Which of the following is a voltage-gated calcium channel present on the T tubule?
questions.solution:
The dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) is a voltage-gated L-type calcium channel located on the T-tubule membrane of skeletal muscle.

When the T-tubule membrane depolarizes during an action potential, the DHPR undergoes a conformational change and mechanically interacts with the ryanodine receptor (RyR1) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR). This triggers the release of Ca²‚Å∫ from the SR into the cytoplasm, leading to muscle contraction.

  • Ryanodine receptor: Calcium-release channel on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, not on the T-tubule.

  • Troponin complex: Located on actin filaments, binds calcium to initiate contraction.

  • SERCA (Sarcoplasmic Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase): Pumps calcium back into the SR during relaxation.

Thus, the voltage-gated calcium channel on the T-tubule is the dihydropyridine receptor.

questions.text: Conscious proprioception is carried by?
questions.solution:
Conscious proprioception refers to the awareness of the position and movement of body parts. This sensory information is carried by the dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway.

  • Pathway:

    • First-order neurons → Dorsal root ganglion

    • Ascend ipsilaterally in the fasciculus gracilis (lower limb) and fasciculus cuneatus (upper limb) of the dorsal column

    • Synapse in nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus in the medulla

    • Second-order neurons → decussate and ascend as medial lemniscus to the thalamus (VPL nucleus)

    • Third-order neurons → somatosensory cortex

Other tracts:

  • Vestibular tract: Maintains balance and posture (not proprioception).

  • Anterior spinothalamic tract: Carries crude touch and pressure.

  • Lateral spinothalamic tract: Carries pain and temperature.

Hence, dorsal column fibers carry conscious proprioception.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with easy fatiguability and was diagnosed as iron deficiency anemia. She was advised to take oral iron supplements. Foods containing which of the following should not be taken along with her iron supplements?
questions.solution:
Iron absorption is influenced by dietary factors:

  • Enhancers:

    • Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) and citrus fruits increase non-heme iron absorption by reducing ferric iron (Fe³‚Å∫) to ferrous iron (Fe²‚Å∫).

  • Inhibitors:

    • Tea contains tannins which bind iron and reduce its absorption.

    • Other inhibitors include coffee, phytates (in cereals/legumes), and calcium.

  • Sugars in diet generally do not inhibit iron absorption.

Clinical tip: Iron supplements should be taken on an empty stomach or with Vitamin C-rich foods, and tea or coffee should be avoided around the time of ingestion.

questions.text: You are performing a CNS examination on a patient with a stroke. With his eyes closed, you move his big toe up or down while holding his metatarsophalangeal joint. You ask him to state the position of the digit. Which of the following fibers is responsible for the transmission of the sensation tested here?
questions.solution:
The test described is for conscious proprioception (joint position sense) of the big toe.

Key points:

  • Conscious proprioception is transmitted via the dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway.

  • The sensory receptors involved include muscle spindles, joint receptors, and skin mechanoreceptors.

  • These receptors transmit signals through large, myelinated Aβ fibers, which are fast-conducting and responsible for fine touch, vibration, and proprioception.

Other fibers:

  • Aα fibers: Motor fibers to skeletal muscles (also some proprioception via muscle spindle afferents, but primarily for reflexes).

  • Aγ fibers: Motor fibers to intrafusal muscle fibers of muscle spindles.

  • AΦ fibers: Not a standard classification (likely meant Aδ fibers, which carry pain and temperature).

Hence, Aβ fibers mediate the conscious perception of joint position tested in this maneuver.

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporter is present in skeletal muscles and adipose tissues?
questions.solution:
• GLUT4 is an insulin-dependent glucose transporter found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue.

  • Mechanism: In response to insulin, GLUT4 translocates from intracellular vesicles to the plasma membrane, allowing glucose uptake.

  • Other transporters:

    • GLUT2: Found in liver, pancreatic β-cells, and kidney; responsible for bidirectional glucose transport.

    • GLUT5: Found in intestinal mucosa; transports fructose.

    • SGLT-1: Sodium-glucose cotransporter in the small intestine and kidney, mediates active glucose absorption.

Hence, the glucose transporter present in skeletal muscles and adipose tissues is GLUT4.

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
Migrating Motor Complex (MMC)
Overview: The migrating motor complex is a pattern of electromechanical activity in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract that occurs during fasting, facilitating the clearance of residual food and digestive secretions.

Phases:

Phase I: Quiescent Period
• Characterized by minimal electrical and mechanical activity.
Phase II: Irregular Electrical & Mechanical Activity
• Features sporadic contractions and fluctuating electrical activity, preparing the intestine for subsequent phases.
Phase III: Burst of Regular Activity
• Ends with a series of strong, regular contractions, effectively pushing intestinal contents toward the colon.
Timing and Function:
• The MMC occurs approximately every 100 minutes and moves in an aboral (away from the mouth) direction at a rate of about 5 cm/min.
• Its primary role is to clear intestinal contents and prepare the GI tract for the next meal, helping to maintain gut health and prevent bacterial overgrowth.

questions.text: Kinesin, Dyenin and Myosin proteins are examples of?
questions.solution:
Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are examples of molecular motors, each playing crucial roles in cellular transport and movement.

• Kinesin:
Structure: The conventional form of kinesin is a double-headed molecule.
Function: It moves cargo toward the plus ("+") ends of microtubules.
Roles: Some kinesins are involved in mitosis and meiosis, while others may move cargo toward the minus ("-") end of microtubules.

• Dynein:
Structure: Dyneins also have two heads, with neckpieces embedded in a complex of proteins.
Function: Cytoplasmic dyneins move particles and membranes toward the minus ("-") end of microtubules, similar to conventional kinesin but in the opposite direction.

• Myosin:
Classes: There are about 18 classes of myosins.
Function: The heads of some myosin molecules (e.g., myosin II) bind to actin filaments and produce movement by bending their neck regions, facilitating muscle contraction and other cellular movements.
These molecular motors are essential for various cellular processes, including intracellular transport, muscle contraction, and cell division.

questions.text: After consuimng three cones of ice cream, a man notices that his ear feels colder than the central part of his body. which area of the brain regulates body temperature?
questions.solution:
The hypothalamus is the primary regulator of body temperature (thermoregulation).

Key points:

  • The preoptic area of the anterior hypothalamus contains thermoreceptors that detect core body temperature.

  • It maintains homeostasis by initiating:

    • Heat loss mechanisms: vasodilation, sweating

    • Heat conservation/generation: shivering, vasoconstriction, brown fat activation

  • Peripheral thermoreceptors (skin, extremities) provide input to the hypothalamus to adjust central body temperature.

Other structures:

  • Amygdala: Emotion processing, fear response

  • Thalamus: Sensory relay, not primary thermoregulator

  • Caudate nucleus: Part of basal ganglia, motor coordination

questions.text: Which of the following hormone acts via this pathway?
questions.solution:
The image illustrates the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which is linked to tyrosine kinase receptors. Among the listed hormones, leptin utilizes this pathway.

Hormones that signal through receptor tyrosine kinases or the JAK-STAT pathway include:

- Growth hormone
- Fibroblast growth factor
- Hepatocyte growth factor
- Insulin
- Insulin-like growth factor-1
- Leptin
- Prolactin
- Vascular endothelial growth factor

Leptin, a hormone produced by fat cells, plays a key role in regulating appetite and energy balance. Its receptor functions through the tyrosine kinase activity of the Janus kinase (JAK) family, specifically JAK2. When leptin binds to the extracellular domain of its receptor, it triggers the phosphorylation (P) and activation of JAK2 on the intracellular side. This leads to the phosphorylation of signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) proteins, which in turn promotes the transcription of specific target genes and protein synthesis.

Additionally, JAK2 phosphorylation activates other intracellular signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK) and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathways.

 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 63,64,319,326 .

choices.text: Rectal temperature is lower than axillary temperature
Rectal temperature is ideal for measuring the core body temperature
Rectal temperature is higher than tympanic membrane temperature
Oral temperature is lower than rectal temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following options is false regarding the measurement of temperature in a febrile patient?
questions.solution:
Rectal temperature represents the core body temperature and is less affected by changes in environmental temperature. It remains relatively constant. In comparison, oral temperature is typically 0.5°C lower than rectal temperature. However, the oral temperature can be influenced by various factors such as consuming hot or cold fluids, chewing gum, smoking, and breathing through the mouth.

Tympanic membrane thermometers measure radiant heat emitted by the tympanic membrane and the nearby ear canal, providing an absolute value of temperature. Tympanic membrane readings are generally 0.8°C (1.6°F) lower than rectal temperatures. The axillary temperature


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 310 .

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about skeletal muscle?
A. Contraction does not rely on extracellular calcium.
B. Mitochondria are not the primary source of calcium release.
C. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is the main source of calcium release.
D. The voltage-gated calcium channel on the sarcolemma does not contribute to excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.solution:
•The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is a key aspect of skeletal muscle function.
•Excitation-contraction coupling describes the mechanism where muscle fiber membrane depolarization (excitation) results in muscle contraction.
•To achieve maximum skeletal muscle contraction, the action potentials must penetrate deeply into the muscle fiber to reach the myofibrils. This deep penetration is facilitated by the action potentials traveling along transverse tubules (T tubules), which extend through the muscle fiber from one side to the other.
•The sarcoplasmic reticulum stores calcium ions at high concentrations within its vesicular tubules. When an action potential travels along the adjacent T tubule, it triggers the release of calcium ions from these vesicles into the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils, leading to muscle contraction.
•When the action potential reaches the T tubule, it activates dihydropyridine receptors connected to calcium release channels. The activation of these receptors causes the opening of the calcium release channels, allowing calcium ions to flow into the sarcoplasm and induce contraction.
•In skeletal muscles, extracellular calcium contributes partially to the maintenance of muscle contraction.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 105 .

questions.text: Cells with smooth endoplasmis reticulum secrete-
questions.solution:
Cells that produce steroid hormones extensively feature smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

The endoplasmic reticulum consists of a complex network of tubules within the cell‘s cytoplasm.

In the rough (granular) endoplasmic reticulum, ribosomes are attached to the cytoplasmic side of the membrane. This structure is responsible for protein synthesis, initial folding of polypeptide chains, and the formation of disulfide bonds.

Ribosomes are not present in the smooth (agranular) endoplasmic reticulum, but free ribosomes are found in the cytoplasm. The smooth ER is involved in steroid synthesis in steroid-secreting cells and in detoxification processes in other cells.

The sarcoplasmic reticulum, a specialized form of endoplasmic reticulum, serves as an intracellular calcium reservoir. It releases calcium into the cytoplasm, which stimulates processes such as cell contraction, proliferation, and migration.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 43,44 .

questions.text:
Arrange the following bands in the sarcomere from the periphery to the center.
A. Z line
B. M line
C. A band
D. H zone
questions.solution:
The correct order of bands in the sarcomere, from the outer edge to the center, is: Z line > A band > H zone > M line.

IThe sarcomere is the fundamental contractile unit of the skeletal muscle fiber.

• The Z line anchors the actin filaments, and the region between two adjacent Z lines is referred to as the sarcomere. It consists of both thick and thin filaments:

- Thick filament: Myosin
- Thin filaments: Actin, tropomyosin, and troponin

• The I band is isotropic to light and contains only actin filaments.

• The A band is anisotropic to light and includes myosin as well as overlapping actin filaments.


• The H band is a lighter region in the center of the A band where the thick filaments do not overlap with the thin filaments when the muscle is relaxed.

• The M line, located at the center of the H band, features slender cross-connections that maintain the organization of the thick filaments.


Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 100-102 .

questions.text: Our bodies are designed to detect harmful substances through the perception of bitter taste. Which of the following substances is responsible for this bitter taste?
questions.solution:
Alkaloids produce a very bitter taste, leading to the rejection of the food. Bitter taste sensations are attributed to two main types of substances:

• Long-chain organic compounds containing nitrogen
. • Alkaloids

Alkaloids are responsible for an intensely bitter flavor that causes the rejection of certain foods. They are present in many medicinal drugs, including quinine, caffeine, strychnine, and nicotine. The bitter taste associated with many dangerous toxins in poisonous plants is also due to alkaloids, which helps in avoiding the harmful food.

Sweet taste results from chemicals such as sugars, glycols, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, amides, esters, some amino acids, certain small proteins, sulfonic acids, halogenated acids, and inorganic salts of lead and beryllium.

Sour taste is caused by acids, with the intensity of the sourness being directly related to the strength of the acid.



Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook Of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, page no 674,675  .

questions.text:
Assertion: RMP is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.
Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using the Nernst Equation. RMP – Resting membrane potential
1. The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reason is independently a true statement
2. The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.
3. Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.
4. Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
questions.solution:
Both the assertion and reason are independently true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.

Resting membrane potential (RMP) refers to the difference in electrical potential between the cell‘s cytoplasm and the extracellular space. It represents an equilibrium where the concentration gradients of ions across the membrane are balanced by opposing electrical gradients.

RMP is mainly influenced by sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions, along with negatively charged intracellular proteins and organic phosphates. In neurons, potassium concentration is higher inside the cell, while sodium is more concentrated outside. This concentration difference is maintained by the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. Potassium ions move passively out of the cell, whereas sodium ions move in.

The resting membrane potential is calculated using the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation, which accounts for the involvement of multiple ions. Potassium, due to its higher conductance across the membrane at rest, is the primary contributor to the RMP.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 6,8,9 .

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal constituent of serum osmolality?
questions.solution:
The main determinant of serum osmolality is sodium.

Serum osmolality is calculated as:
Serum osmolality = 2 [Sodium] + (Glucose ÷ 18) + (BUN ÷ 2.8).

The key factors influencing serum osmolality are the concentrations of sodium, glucose, and urea (measured as blood urea nitrogen, or BUN).

Osmolality is a measure of the number of solute particles (osmoles) per kilogram of solvent (Osm/kg or osmol/kg). The osmolality of both intracellular and extracellular fluids is typically maintained between 290 and 310 mOsm/kg.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which of the following proteins during smooth muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Calcium binds to calmodulin during smooth muscle contraction.
sequence of events in smooth muscle contraction:
• Binding of acetylcholine to muscarinic receptors
• Increased influx of Ca2+ into the cell • Ca2+ bond to calmodulin
• Activation of calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase
• Myosin phosphorylation
• Increased myosin ATPase activity and binding of myosin to actin. Ref- Ganong Review of Medical Physiology 26th edition Page 105,106

questions.text: Aquaporin channels transport water molecules across a cell membrane through which type of transport mechanism ?
questions.solution:
Aquaporin is a carrier protein that transports water molecules across cell membrane in response to osmotic gradient. It is a type of facilitated diffusion. When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion. -Simple diffusion is the movement of molecules through a cell membrane without using the channels formed by integral membrane protein.
- Primary active transport is a process that uses chemical energy to move substances across a cell membrane against their concentration gradient -Secondary active transport is where two or more molecules are transported together across the membrane with the help of a carrier molecule. Example sodium glucose cotransporter SGLT-1. As sodium diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, the energy released is used to drive glucose against the gradient. It does not require energy directly from ATP.
Guyton and Hall's Textbook of Medical Physiology 10th Edition • Page 56-58

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits ferroportin?
questions.solution:
Chronic inflammation causes the release of IL-6, an inflammatory mediator that inhibits ferroportin by inducing the production of hepcidin in the liver. Hepcidin is an essential factor in controlling the absorption of iron.

Heme and non-heme iron are the two types of dietary iron. Duodenal cytochrome B, also known as ferric reductase, or vitamin C are first required to convert ferric non-heme iron to ferrous iron. The enterocyte then absorbs this decreased ferrous iron by the divalent metal transporter, or DMT1. along certain transporters, heme iron enters the cytoplasm where it is broken down to produce ferrous iron, which travels along the same route as non-heme iron.



Reference
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e - Page No: 658, 659, 848

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles is associated with killing bacteria and viruses?
questions.solution:
Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain hydrolytic enzymes capable of digesting a wide variety of biomolecules, including:

  • Bacteria

  • Viruses

  • Damaged organelles

  • Cellular debris

Lysosomes are crucial in:

  • Phagocytosis: digesting pathogens engulfed by immune cells (e.g., macrophages, neutrophils)

  • Autophagy: degrading worn-out cellular components

  • Defense against infections

    Other options:

  • Peroxisomes: Detoxify hydrogen peroxide and oxidize fatty acids, but are not primary pathogen killers.

  • Golgi complex: Modifies, packages, and transports proteins—not involved in pathogen destruction.

  • Ribosomes: Responsible for protein synthesis, not defense or digestion.


Reference: Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no 37-38

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy living near the sea mistakenly consumes pufferfish and complains of vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain with ascending paralysis, and eventually dies with respiratory failure. The toxin in this poisoning acts mainly on which of the following channels?
questions.solution:
The poison tetrodotoxin is the cause of puffer fish poisoning. Primarily, this toxin affects the sodium channels.

By inhibiting sodium channels, this toxin is also utilized to investigate the flow of ions across different specific channels. For example, when tetrodotoxin is administered to the exterior of the cell membrane where the sodium activation gates are located, it blocks the sodium channels.

Mechanism of Action of Tetrodotoxin:

  • Tetrodotoxin blocks voltage-gated sodium (Na‚Å∫) channels in nerve and muscle membranes.

  • This prevents depolarization and inhibits action potential conduction.

  • The result is paralysis, starting in the extremities and ascending, eventually involving respiratory muscles leading to respiratory failure and death.

    Clinical Features of Tetrodotoxin Poisoning:

  • Rapid onset of:

    • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain

    • Numbness, paresthesia

    • Ascending flaccid paralysis

    • Respiratory muscle paralysis

    • Consciousness usually preserved until late stage



Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 1863

questions.text: The following process where transportation is along the concentration gradient is an example of:
questions.solution:
• GLUT (Glucose Transporter) proteins mediate the passive movement of glucose down its concentration gradient.

  • This process does not require ATP and does not involve sodium coupling.

  • Instead, it uses facilitated diffusion – a type of passive transport where a specific carrier protein helps a molecule cross the membrane.

    Types of GLUT Transporters:

    GLUT Type Location Key Role
    GLUT-1 RBCs, brain, cornea Basal glucose uptake
    GLUT-2 Liver, pancreas β-cells, kidney Bidirectional – glucose in & out
    GLUT-3 Neurons High-affinity transporter
    GLUT-4 Muscle, adipose (insulin-sensitive) Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake
    GLUT-5 Intestine Fructose transporter

Types of Transport Across Cell Membranes
Type of Transport Examples
Simple Diffusion O‚ÇÇ, CO‚ÇÇ, steroids
Facilitated Diffusion Glucose via GLUT, urea, amino acids
Primary Active Transport Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫ ATPase, Ca²‚Å∫ ATPase, H‚Å∫/K‚Å∫ ATPase
Secondary Active Transport SGLT (Na‚Å∫-glucose cotransport), Na‚Å∫/Ca²‚Å∫ exchanger
Endocytosis LDL uptake, receptor-mediated endocytosis
Exocytosis Neurotransmitter release, hormone secretion (insulin)

Reference: Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no. 48

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in strenuous exercise?
questions.solution:
During strenuous exercise, the following physiological changes occur:

  • Lactic acidosis: Yes — due to increased anaerobic glycolysis in muscles.

  • Endogenous opioid release: Yes — the body releases endorphins to reduce pain and promote a sense of well-being.

  • Right shift of O‚ÇÇ-Hb dissociation curve: Yes — caused by increased CO‚ÇÇ, increased temperature, and decreased pH, which enhances oxygen delivery to tissues.

  • Hypokalemia: No — actually, transient hyperkalemia occurs due to the release of potassium from contracting skeletal muscles into the bloodstream.

Hence, hypokalemia is not seen in strenuous exercise.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical physiology 13th edition page no 390

questions.text: If the capillary hydrostatic pressure is 25 mm Hg and the interstitial hydrostatic pressure is 2 mm Hg, respectively, then the interstitial oncotic pressure is 7 mm Hg. What capillary oncotic pressure must exist for a 3 mm Hg net filtration pressure to be possible?
questions.solution:
By, Starling's equation
Filtration Pressure = Kf[(Pgc - Pt) - (pgc - pbs)]

3=(25-2)-(pgc-7)
3=23-pgc+7
Therefore, pgc=27
Where
Kf = glomerular filtration coefficient (product of glomerular surface times hydraulic conductivity)
Pgc = capillary hydrostatic pressure
Pbs = interstitial hydrostatic pressure
pgc = capillary oncotic pressure
pbs = interstitial oncotic pressure


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

questions.text: Unless there is significant crosslinking, the clot formed is not stable. What is responsible for the extensive cross-linking of the blood clot?
questions.solution:
Factor XIII extensively crosses-links blood clots and stabilizes it. It is,therefore, known as fibrin-stabilizing factor Laki-Lorand factor.


NB- New theory suggests factor VIIa of extrinsic pathway can activate factor XI and IX of intrinsic pathway and finally form a clot.

It is stored in Weibel Palade bodies of endothelial cell. Damage to endothelial cells results in oozing of vWF outside where it helps in anchorage of platelets to subendothelial collagen.

questions.text: What does erythropoietin act on?
questions.solution:
Kidney-derived cytokine erythropoietin stimulates the terminal proliferation and differentiation of Colony Forming Unit (CFU)-Erythroid progenitors.
 
  • Erythropoietin (EPO) increases the development, differentiation, and proliferation of erythroid precursors, increasing erythrocyte numbers while having a negligible impact on megakaryocytes.

questions.text: A trauma patient arrives at the emergency room. There is no time for cross-matching. Which group's Fresh frozen plasma(FFP) can be safely transfused?
questions.solution:
Correct option is (3) AB RhD+. 

Please note, the question is asking about plasma - not RBCs.  O being universal donor is valid for RBCs(since individuals with O blood group do not have any antigens on RBC), but not for Plasma.  Plasma of individuals with O blood group will have antibodies against both A and B.
For plasma transfusion - individual with AB blood group - their plasma will not have any antibodies - hence, can be transfused to anyone



It should be AB Rh+ as both plasmas of AB and Rh won't have antibodies(be it against A/B or against Rh factor)and can be safely transfused to anyone. Individuals with Rh negative blood group can sometime have antibodies against Rh in their plasma.

questions.text: Which of the following pathways is activated when calcium and thromboplastin are added to platelet-poor plasma for the purpose of estimating prothrombin time (PT)?
questions.solution:
In Prothrombin time (PT) estimation, addition of calcium and thromboplastin to platelet poor plasma activates extrinsic
pathway.

The prothrombin time (PT) assay evaluates how well the extrinsic pathway's proteins work (factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen). The time it takes for a fibrin clot to form is measured when tissue factor, phospholipids, and calcium are added to the plasma.

Trick to memorize:- 
PT- short word(2 letters) so shorter pathway - extrinsic pathway
aPTT- bigger word(4 letters) so longer pathway- intrinsic pathway


Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 662

questions.text: Hematopoietic Stem Cells differ from Committed Progenitor Cells in being able to?
questions.solution:
Hematopoietic stem cells are examples of multipotent cells whereby they can form more than one category of cells such as myeloid and lymphoid lineage. Committed progenitor cells, on the other hand,  are examples of oligopotent cells where they can form only one category of cells- example- erythroblast. 

unique properties of HSC -
1. Asymmetric division- self renewal 
2. Not sessile - they can be mobilised to peripheral blood - eg: Sepsis, GM-CSF administration 
3. Transdifferentiation/Developmental plasticity- can be converted to other lineage of cells like neurons, muscles etc

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 544

questions.text:
The cell counts in various Neubauer's chamber squares after charging with 20 times diluted blood are shown in the following picture. What is the total number of leukocytes?


1. 6000/mm3
2. 2400/mm3
3.  3000/mm3
4. 14200/mm3
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 6000/mm3

The method used here is called Total leukocyte counting (TLC) Principle of the TLC method:
  1. Blood is diluted with a fluid that causes the RBCs’ hemolysis, but WBCs remain intact, and then these are counted in the Neubauer chamber.
  2. Gentian violet lightly stains the leucocytes and allows those to be counted.
          Each of the square has a dimension of 1mm x lmm. Depth is 0.1 mm.
          Volume of one square = (1 x 1 x 0.1) mm3 = 0.1 mm3
          Concentration of cells = n/V x d
          (n= No. of cells, V= Volume of distribution, d= Dilution)
          Cells counted in 4 corner squares = n = (25 + 35 + 40 + 20) = 120
          Total Volume of 4 squares = 4 x 0.1 = 0.4 mm3
          Dilution factor = 20
          WbC Count = 120/0.4 x 20 = 6000 cells/mm3


Reference- https://www.emsdiasum.com/docs/technical/datasheet/68052-14

questions.text: At what temperature are RBCs stored?

  • Platelet- 5 days- 20-24 degree Celsius (room temperature)
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma- 1 year- -30 degree Celsius

The GPIb-IX-V complex binds to the exposed von-Willebrand factor, causing platelets to adhere.

questions.text: In cases of severe anaemia, cyanosis does not manifest because
questions.solution:
Cyanosis is a dusky blue discoloration of the skin caused by blood in the capillaries containing reduced hemoglobin when its concentration exceeds >5 g/dL in blood. Anemic individuals already have severely depleted hemoglobin levels (sometimes lower than 5g/dL) and hence, this critical concentration of reduced hemoglobin is not reached to manifest cyanosis.

questions.text: ESR testing is very important in the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Which statement regarding ESR in TB is accurate?
questions.solution:
The ESR is a non-specific test to detect inflammation in the body.
During inflammation positive phase reactants like fibrinogen is increased.
It is based on the phenomenon of fibrinogen binding to red cells and causing them to form stacks (rouleaux), which sediment faster at unit gravity than individual cells( hence, ESR being higher or raised).
This is used to measure the presence of inflammation and is a useful indicator of tissue damage or disease in the body.
In TB - there would be inflammation causing a higher ESR.

questions.text: Which of these produces vWF
Which clotting factor deficiency will have no effect on clotting in vivo
questions.solution:
Among the clotting factor deficits listed, the clotting factor deficit that has no impact on clotting in vivo is factor XII (option 4). Factor XII, also known as Hageman factor, plays a role in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. However, its deficiency does not generally lead to bleeding or clotting abnormalities. This is because factor XII deficiency is not associated with significant clinical manifestations or bleeding disorders in most individuals.

Some coagulation factors and the diseases linked with their deficiency are:

   

According to new evidence, factor VIIa from the extrinsic pathway can activate factors XI and IX of intrinsic pathway, hence doing same work as that of XII, therefore factor XII deficiency doesn’t manifest much clinically.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Rh incompatibility is false?
questions.solution:
Increase in urine bilirubin will be incorrect in Rh incompatibility.

Hyperbilirubinemia occurs due to increase in destruction of RBCs in case of Rh incompatibility. The increased bilirubin is bound with albumin as it is water insoluble and does not appear in urine.

Increased RBC lysis will lead to increased production of bilirubin and will be metabolized to urobilinogen leading to increased urobilinogen in urine and stool.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the most likely cause/explanation: where a 32 year old high altitude mountaineer is observed to have a hematocrit of 70 percent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Polycythemia with increased red cell mass 

In high altitude due to decreased atmospheric oxygen the partial pressure of oxygen falls. Thereby ventilation increases which leads to carbon dioxide washout à and this finally causes Respiratory Alkalosis.
Chronic increase in ventilation leads to the following changes as under :-
  • Increase in Erythropoietin leads to increase in Haemoglobin & Haematocrit
  • Increase in 2,3-BPG à causes Right shift of Oxygen Haemoglobin Dissociation curveà Leading to Oxygen Release
  • Cellular changes like Increase in mitochondria
  • Increased renal excretion of Bicarbonate ions to compensate for Respiratory Alkalosis
  • Chronic Hypoxic Pulmonary Vasoconstriction leads to increased pulmonary vascular resistance à leads to Pulmonary Hypertension , Right ventricular hypertrophy

[FREQUENTLY TESTED à ACETAZOLAMIDE IS GIVEN IN THE TREATMENT; NOT DIGOXIN]


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 639,638

choices.text: Factors X is part of both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways
Extrinsic pathway is activated by contact with negatively charged surfaces
Intrinsic pathway can be activated in vitro
Calcium is required in several steps of coagulation

questions.text: All of the following are true about blood coagulation, except
questions.solution:
• Blood coagulation is a complex process that involves multiple pathways and factors. The intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are two important pathways that lead to the formation of a blood clot. Factor X is a common factor in both pathways, and its activation is essential for the formation of a blood clot. Therefore, option 1 is correct.
  • Option 2 states that the extrinsic pathway is activated by contact with negatively charged surfaces, which is not true. The extrinsic pathway is primarily activated by tissue factor (TF), which is a transmembrane protein present on the surface of cells outside the blood vessels. When there is tissue damage, TF is exposed to the blood, and it activates factor VII, which then activates factor X. Therefore, option 2 is incorrect.
  • Option 3 is true, as the intrinsic pathway can be activated in vitro (outside the body) by contact with artificial surfaces or negatively charged substances.
  • Option 4 is also true, as calcium ions play a crucial role in several steps of blood coagulation, including the activation of factor X and the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.
  • In summary, all options except option 2 are true about blood coagulation.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 555,556

questions.text: Fructosamine is the glycated product of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Fructosamine is the glycated product of albumin.
 
  • Fructosamine refers to glycated serum proteins, of which albumin is the most abundant.


Clinical Use:

  • Useful for monitoring glycemic control in conditions where HbA1c measurements are unreliable, such as:
    • Hemoglobinopathies (e.g., sickle cell anemia, thalassemia).
    • Conditions with altered red cell turnover (e.g., anemia, recent blood loss).
    • Pregnancy, where shorter-term glucose monitoring is important.
  • May also be used in gestational diabetes and rapidly changing glucose control settings.
  • It will give us the glycemic control of the last 3 weeks

questions.text:
Iron overload in body detected by: 
(i) Heart iron level by scan 
(ii) Liver load 
(iii) Ferritin 
(iv) DMT-1
questions.solution:
DMT-1 is an iron transporter that moves Fe+2 and other bivalent ions from the luminal side of the intestine to the enterocytes and it is not specific for Fe+2
Rest 3 options can be used to detect iron overload in the body
 

Iron overload in the body can be detected by the following:

  1. Heart iron level by scan (i): Cardiac MRI with T2* imaging is used to measure iron deposition in the heart, especially in conditions like thalassemia or hemochromatosis.

  2. Liver load (ii): The liver is a primary site of iron storage, and liver iron concentration (LIC) can be measured via MRI or liver biopsy to assess iron overload.

  3. Ferritin (iii): Serum ferritin levels are often elevated in iron overload conditions and serve as an indirect marker of iron stores. However, it can also be elevated in inflammation or other conditions.

(iv) DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1) is not used to detect iron overload. It is a protein involved in iron absorption and transport, but it is not a diagnostic marker.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 655-657.

questions.text: What cells are present in the center of the lumen of venules?
questions.solution:
• Red blood cells (RBCs) tend to occupy the axial (central) flow of small blood vessels, including venules, due to laminar flow dynamics.

  • White blood cells (neutrophils, lymphocytes) are larger and less deformable, so they tend to marginate along the endothelial lining (the periphery of the lumen) — a phenomenon called margination.

  • During inflammation, neutrophils adhere to the endothelium and later transmigrate, but they are still mostly at the vessel periphery, not in the center.

So, in the center of venules, the predominant cells are RBCs, while neutrophils line the walls.

questions.text: Hemoglobin with iron in ferric form is
questions.solution:
Methemoglobin is characterized by hemoglobin containing iron in the ferric (Fe3+) form.

Hemoglobin consists of a tetramer formed by globin polypeptide chains, specifically two alpha chains and two beta chains.

HbA (α2β2): Major adult hemoglobin
HbF (α2γ2): Fetal hemoglobin
HbA2 (α2δ2): Minor adult hemoglobin

Each globin chain encloses a single heme moiety, which consists of a protoporphyrin IX ring complexed with a single iron atom in the ferrous (Fe2+) state.

Each heme moiety has the capacity to bind one molecule of oxygen. Thus, one Hb molecule can bind to up to 4 Oxygen molecules, and the binding of one oxygen molecule increases the affinity of hemoglobin for subsequent oxygen molecules. This phenomenon is known as the cooperative binding of Hb.


Methemoglobin Formation:

In methemoglobinemia, the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from Fe²‚Å∫ (ferrous) to Fe³‚Å∫ (ferric) form. Ferric iron cannot bind oxygen, so although hemoglobin is present, it is non-functional for oxygen transport. This leads to reduced oxygen delivery to tissues, despite normal PaO‚ÇÇ, resulting in anemic type of hypoxia.
 

  • Iron state: Fe³‚Å∫ (ferric)

  • Oxygen binding: Cannot bind oxygen → functional anemia

  • Formation: Oxidation of Fe²‚Å∫ in hemoglobin to Fe³‚Å∫

  • Clinical significance: Leads to methemoglobinemia

  • Causes:

    • Congenital (deficiency of NADH–cytochrome b5 reductase)

    • Acquired (drugs like nitrates, dapsone, local anesthetics)

  • Appearance: Chocolate-brown colored blood

  • Treatment: Methylene blue (reduces Fe³‚Å∫ back to Fe²‚Å∫)

Other Options:

Option B and D: Fetal Hb and HbA contain Iron in ferrous form (Fe2+), and their structure differs due to different globin chain combinations as mentioned above.

Option C: HbS also contains iron in ferrous form. It is seen in patient's with sickle cell anemia, due to point mutation in the gene encoding for beta globin chain.

questions.text: A pregnant couple presented to the OPD with concerns about thalassemia in their baby due to a positive family history. Genetic studies revealed that both she and her husband are carriers. What is the probability that the child will have thalassemia major?
questions.solution:
The likelihood of Thalassemia major in children of two carrier parents is 25%. 
 

Thalassemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

If both parents are carriers (heterozygous, Tt):

  • Possible genotypes of child:

    • TT (normal): 25%

    • Tt (carrier): 50%

    • tt (thalassemia major): 25%

So, the probability that the child will have thalassemia major is 25% (0.25).




Reference
Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition - Page no: 644, 646-647

questions.solution:

Long term potentiation
Long-term potentiation is a fast-developing and prolonged enhancement of the postsynaptic potential response, after a brief period of rapidly repeated stimulation of the potentiation neuron. It occurs due to an accumulation of Ca2+ in the postsynaptic neuron
LTP is a type of synaptic plasticity where there is generation of new synapses associated with memory formation in hippocampus

questions.text: Which are the adrenergic beta-receptors that have the ability to cause lipolysis in fat cells?
questions.solution:
The adrenergic receptor that primarily mediates lipolysis (breakdown of fat) in fat cells is the beta-3 adrenergic receptor .Activation of β3 receptors leads to an increase in the intracellular levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP), which in turn activates hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for catalyzing the breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, which are released into the bloodstream.

Other adrenergic receptors, such as the alpha-1 and beta-1 receptors, do not significantly contribute to lipolysis in fat cells. Therefore, β3 adrenergic receptors are specifically targeted in therapeutic approaches aimed at promoting fat breakdown in adipose tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to fibers that directly connect to the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum?
questions.solution:

  •  Each one projects to a Purkinje cell's major dendrites, where it intertwines like a climbing plant. The inferior olivary nuclei receive proprioceptive information from everywhere across the body.

questions.text: What mainly regulates CSF pressure?
questions.solution:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure is regulated by the balance between production and absorption of CSF.

The rate of CSF absorption is predominantly determined by the movement of CSF across the arachnoid granulations (AGs) into the dural venous sinuses.

The absorption of CSF into the venous sinuses is driven by higher pressure in the CSF space as compared to that in the capillaries of the venous sinuses.

The rate of CSF then determines the hydrostatic pressure of CSF in the cranial vault, thereby regulating the intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Corticospinal damage is linked to all except:

Clasp-Knife Effect: When the muscles are hypertonic, as in a UMN lesion, the sequence of moderate stretch- strong stretch muscle relaxation is seen. muscle contraction, Passive flexion of the elbow meets immediate resistance as a result of the stretch reflex in the triceps muscle. Further stretch activates the inverse stretch reflex. The resistance to flexion suddenly collapses, and the arm flexes. Continued passive flexion stretches the muscle again, and the sequence is repeated. This sequence of resistance followed by a 'give' when a limb is moved passively is known as the clasp-knife effect because of its resemblance to the closing of a pocket knife. It is also known as lengthening reaction because it is the response of a spastic muscle to lengthening. Clasp knife rigidity occurs due to involvement of Extrapyramidal tracts.
Rest all the 3 are associated with corticospinal tract.

questions.text: Why is it believed that the brain is responsive?
questions.solution:
In humans, the brain is considered to be "responsive" because its functions are affected by changes in the external environment.

For example, changes in the environment (such as a loud noise) can cause the brain to activate certain areas in an attempt to process the change.

The brain is also affected by changes in emotional arousal, where different areas of the brain become more active depending on the emotional context.

Additionally, changes in learning patterns can also cause the brain to rewire itself as new connections are formed and strengthened through repetition.

Finally, when exposed to certain types of drugs or hormones, the brain can make adjustments to its chemistry in order to cope with the changes in the external environment.

Ultimately, the brain is widely seen as being highly responsive to many types of changes in the environment, both physical and emotional.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 151

questions.text: When an excitable tissue, such as a nerve or muscle, is exposed to supramaximal stimulation and a response is produced, in what state is the tissue?
questions.solution:
The absolute refractory period begins once the firing level is reached and continues until repolarization is around one-third complete. Following this is the relative refractory period, in which stronger than usual stimuli can still elicit a response while weaker stimuli will not. During the absolute refractory period, no matter how powerful a stimulus is, the nerve cannot be excited.

questions.text: What are nuclear bag fibres related to?
questions.solution:
When a muscle is stretched and has its nerve intact, the response it produces is known as the stretch reflex. The muscle spindle, a small enclosed fusiform structure within the muscle, is the sensory organ that detects the stretch stimuli. It consists of two subtypes of Nuclear bag fibres which are responsible for detecting both the velocity of the stretch (dynamic) and the steady-state length of the muscle (static).

questions.text: What is the function of mechano stretch receptors in joints and ligaments?

questions.text: When are fast fatigue fibres recruited during walking?
questions.solution:
The motor units are classified according to the type of muscle fibres they innervate, and this categorization is based on the duration of the muscle twitches they produce.

Additionally, the recruitment of motor units during muscle contraction follows a general process known as the Size Principle, where certain types of motor units are recruited to produce specific responses.

Slow S motor units are recruited to initiate a muscle action, followed by faster FR motor units for more powerful responses over shorter time periods, and finally the most fatigable FF motor units for the most demanding tasks.

questions.text: Mediators of ganglionic transmission include:
questions.solution:
Ganglionic transmission is mediated by nicotinic receptors present postsynaptically. In both divisions of the autonomic nervous system, postganglionic neurons express nicotinic acetylcholine receptors to receive signals from preganglionic neurons. The neurotransmitters of postganglionic fibers differ. In the parasympathetic division, neurons are cholinergic (that is, acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter).

In the sympathetic division, neurons are mostly adrenergic (that is, epinephrine and norepinephrine function as the primary neurotransmitters).

questions.text: What is the basis for transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation?

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not felt by the trigeminal nerve's spinal nucleus?

questions.text: Which type of feedback is Baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
The baroreceptor reflex is a rapid negative feedback system which results in the heart rate falling and blood pressure decreasing after an increase in such is detected. If a decrease in blood pressure is detected, the baroreflex is deactivated, which leads to an increase in heart rate and returns the blood pressure back to its typical levels.

questions.text: Abdominal spasm discomfort is reduced by using a hot water bottle via:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Stimulation of adrenergic fibers

Gate Control Theory of pain suggests that the spinal cord has a neurological 'gate' that controls pain signals to the brain. It asserts that non-painful input closes the nerve "gates" to painful input, which prevents pain sensation from traveling to the central nervous system
  • Visceral pain from the gastrointestinal tract is largely mediated by pain relaying ‘C’ fibers that run almost exclusively in the sympathetic (adrenergic) system
  • Heat impulses from hot water bottles are transmitted through larger A fibers and C fibers which have higher velocity
  • Relief of pain with a hot water bottle involves modulation of sympathetic pathways through stimulation of the ‘A’ and ‘C’ fibers thereby blocking the pain sensation carried by small ‘C’ fibers.

questions.text:
Release of ACh is enhanced by blocking which of the following?
1. Voltage gated Na+ channel block presynaptically
2. Cl- channel block presynaptically 
3. K+ channel block presynaptically 
4. Ca2+ channel block presynaptically
questions.solution:
Blocking the potassium channels on presynaptic membrane enhances acetylcholine release. Blocking potassium channel pre-synaptically leads to depolarisation that leads to Ca++ channel opening and Ca++ ion entry that leads to release of neurotransmitters.

Acetylcholine (ACh) is a neurotransmitter that is stored in vesicles and is released when an action potential in the motor neuron opens Ca2+ channels in the presynaptic terminal. Each vesicle contains 10,000 molecules of ACh and 60 to 125 vesicles are released with each nerve impulse.

Ach diffuses across the synaptic cleft, allowing Na+ and K+ channels to open and depolarizing the muscle end plate (but not producing an action potential). Local currents in the membrane are induced by depolarization of the muscular end plate, depolarizing the membrane to the threshold and generating action potentials.

questions.text:
Which of the following assertions about the mechanisms of depolarization, repolarization, and hyperpolarization in the skeletal muscle action potential is correct?
A. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
B. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through ligand- gated channels
C. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+through voltage - gated channels
D. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through ligand - gated channel
E. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Skeletal muscle action potential:
  1. Resting membrane potential.
  2. Some voltage gated sodium channels open and sodium enters cell - Threshold potential.
  3. Opening of more voltage gated sodium channels, rapid upstroke - Depolarisation.
  4. Reached to peak level
  5. Sodium channels close with opening of voltage gated potassium channels - Repolarisation
  6. Slow return of potassium channels to closed state - Hyperpolarisation.
  7. Return to resting membrane potential.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 105

questions.text: Sexual activity in males is most closely related to which of the following nucleus of Hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
1. Preoptic nucleus: This nucleus is critically involved in the regulation of sexual behavior in males. It integrates sensory information and hormonal signals that drive sexual arousal and mating behaviors. Activation of the preoptic area is linked to increased sexual motivation and performance.

  2. Supraoptic nucleus: This nucleus primarily regulates the release of hormones, such as oxytocin and vasopressin, which are important for fluid balance and social bonding, but it is not directly involved in the control of sexual behavior.

  3. Lateral hypothalamic nuclei: These nuclei are associated with feeding behavior and the regulation of energy balance. While they can influence motivation and arousal more generally, they are not specifically tied to sexual activity.

  4. Posterior hypothalamic nuclei: This region is more involved in regulating autonomic functions and some aspects of stress response. It does not play a significant role in sexual behavior.

In summary, the preoptic nucleus is the key area associated with sexual activity in males, while the other options have roles in different physiological processes.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 303

questions.text: If all environmental/external cues are removed, which of the following is likely to happen to the 'Sleep-wake cycle'?
questions.solution:
If all environmental or external cues are removed, the sleep-wake cycle is likely to be prolonged to greater than 24 hours (Option 2).

In the absence of external cues, such as light and social interactions, the body's internal biological clock, or circadian rhythm, tends to drift. The natural circadian period for humans is slightly longer than 24 hours, usually around 24.2 to 24.5 hours, which can lead to a gradual shift in the sleep-wake cycle over time.

questions.text: Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the principle behind this?
questions.solution:
• The principle behind Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) for pain relief is the Gate Control Theory of Pain.
  • The Gate Control Theory of Pain suggests that non-painful input can close the "gates" to painful input, which prevents pain sensations from reaching the brain. TENS works by delivering low-level electrical impulses to the skin surface, which stimulates the sensory nerves and activates the non-painful input. This stimulation can close the "gates" to the painful input, reducing the sensation of pain.

questions.text: Which among the following statement is wrong about Brown sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
The wrong statement about Brown-Séquard syndrome among the options provided is:

1. It is a complete section of the spinal cord.

The Brown-Séquard syndrome is not characterized by a complete section or transection of the spinal cord. Instead, it is typically caused by a hemisection or incomplete lesion of the spinal cord, resulting in specific neurological deficits.

The correct features of Brown-Séquard syndrome are:

2. Pain and temperature sensation on the contralateral side are impaired: There is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the side opposite the lesion due to the decussation (crossing) of these sensory fibers in the spinal cord.

3. Complete sensory loss on the ipsilateral side: There is a loss of proprioception, fine touch, vibration sensation, and two-point discrimination on the side of the lesion (ipsilateral side).

4. Fine touch and vibration sensation on the ipsilateral side are impaired: Due to the interruption of the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway on the ipsilateral side, fine touch and vibration sensation are affected on the side of the lesion.

It's important to note that motor function can also be affected in Brown-Séquard syndrome. There is ipsilateral (same side) motor weakness or paralysis due to damage to the corticospinal tract on the same side as the lesion.
 



 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3446 .
