questions.text:
Points A to E are given in the adjoining graph of the action potential. Which of the following is correct?

1. Point A to point C is due to opening of slow Na+ channels
2, Point B to point D is due to opening of fast K+ channels
3. Nerve is hyperexcitable at point E
4. Point A to point D is the refractory period
questions.solution:
Answer(4) Point A to point D is the refractory period.

In the given figure which represents the changes in membrane potential during initiation of an action potential, various events have been marked.
  1. The resting membrane potential of neurons is usually about –70 mV.
  2. In response to a depolarizing stimulus, some of the voltage-gated Na+ channels open and Na+ enters the cell and the membrane is brought to its threshold potential. (point A)
  3. Due to a positive feedback loop, there is a rapid upstroke (point B) till membrane potential reaches maximum/ overshoot. (point C)
  4. The opening of voltage-gated K+ channels contributes to repolarization (point D).
  5. The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state (they stay open resulting in K+ ion loss and further negative charge) explains the after-hyperpolarization (point E), followed by a return to the resting membrane potential. The phase of after-hyperpolarization is also refractory to further stimuli.
* Point A-D is a part of refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not ellicit an action potential.
 



The refractory period is divided into an Absolute and a relative Refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 91.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of trauma. The patient has hemoglobinuria and undergoes a series of laboratory investigations. His potassium is 5.5mmol/L. What is the effect on peripheral neurons?
questions.solution:
Answer(4). RMP becomes more positive

The patient has presented with a history of trauma with hemoglobinuria. This indicates that there is injury to the body tissues at the cellular level leading to leakage of K+ into the blood, leading to hyperkalemia.  
  • The contribution of the K+ channel to the RMP is maximal due to a high coefficient of permeability.
  • Thus, the resting membrane potential is close to the equilibrium potential for K+.
  • It follows that changes in the external concentration of this ion can have major effects on the resting membrane potential.
  • If the extracellular level of K+ is increased (hyperkalemia), the resting potential moves closer to the threshold for eliciting an action potential and the neuron becomes more excitable. (More positive)
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 91, 92.

questions.text: An old patient presented with resting tremor, rigidity and emotional blunting. Which of the following represents the likely site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Answer(1). Basal ganglia

This patient has rigidity, a resting hand tremor, and emotional blunting.
  • These symptoms are most likely due to Parkinson's disease, which is caused by degeneration of the dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. (part of basal ganglia)
  • This loss of dopaminergic neurons leads to a progressive deficiency of dopamine available to inhibit the thalamus.
  • This results in decreased stimulation of the motor cortex by the thalamus, leading to the classic symptoms of bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3387.

questions.text: The subthalamic nuclei of basal ganglia is concerned with which of the following functions?
questions.solution:
Subthalamic nuclei of basal ganglia is associated with motor function, It is concerned with coordination of motor functions via the direct and indirect pathways.
Memory- Hippocampus

Reference: Snell's Clinical Neuroanatomy, 8th Edition, Page No: 311, 312.

questions.text: Which of the following type of pain stimulus is associated with Carrageenan induced experimental pain model?
questions.solution:
Carrageenan induced pain model is model of acute Inflammation.
  • Carrageenan-induced paw edema is one of the most popular tests used in the screening of African spices and vegetables for anti-inflammatory activity.
  • It is a highly sensitive and reproducible test for nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and has long been established as a valid model to study new anti-inflammatory drugs.
  • Carrageenan-induced inflammation is useful in detecting orally active anti-inflammatory agents; therefore, it has significant predictive value for anti-inflammatory agents acting through mediators of acute inflammation.
  • The development of edema induced by carrageenan injection causes an acute and local inflammatory response. In the early phase (0–1 h), histamine, serotonin, and bradykinin are the first mediators involved, whereas prostaglandins and various cytokines such as IL-1β, IL-6, IL-10, and TNF-α are implicated in the second phase.
Reference: Fehrenbacher JC, Vasko MR, Duarte DB. Models of inflammation: Carrageenan- or complete Freund's Adjuvant (CFA)-induced edema and hypersensitivity in the rat. Curr Protoc Pharmacol. 2012 Mar;Chapter 5:Unit5.4. doi: 10.1002/0471141755.ph0504s56. PMID: 22382999; PMCID: PMC4683998.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presented with slowness while carrying out activities, hypophonia, tremors involving his left hand and gait disturbances with a tendency to fall. On examination patient had a positive glabellar tap reflex , festinant gait with re-emerging tremor in his left hand. Which of the following pathways are affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The triad of asymmetrical resting tremors, bradykinesia and rigidity is suggestive of idiopathic parkinsons disease. The main pathogenic mechanism in idiopathic parkinsons disease is the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to dysfunction of the nigrostriatal pathway. This pathway plays a crucial role in regulating voluntary movement by modulating the activity of the basal ganglia.
Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition • Page 148
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 14th Edition

questions.text: A disorder where the patient is unable to recognize or acknowledge their deficits, particularly with regard to sensory or motor functions is termed as ?
questions.solution:
Anosognosia is a disorder where individuals affected by a disease are unable to recognize or acknowledge their deficits, particularly in sensory or motor functions. It is often associated with conditions like hemiplegia and can involve delusional beliefs about body parts.
Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces. Storage and recognition of faces is controlled by the right inferior temporal lobe in right handed individuals. Damage to this region can lead to prosopagnosia. Somatognosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one's own or another's body. Occurs due to lessons involving the contralateral parietal cortex.
Tactile agnosia (aka stereognosia) - inability to recognize. objects by touch, in the presence of intact cutaneous and proprioceptive hand sensation; caused by a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe. Ref- Guyton and Hall 13th edition Page 740

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms as shown in the image below: 1) shows the site of the lesion, 2) has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the same side, and 3) has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes the classic triad of findings seen in Brown-Séquard syndrome, which results from hemisection (half lesion) of the spinal cord.

Key Features of Brown-Séquard Syndrome:

  1. Ipsilateral loss of:

    • Proprioception

    • Vibration

    • Fine/discriminative touch
      → due to damage to the dorsal columns (posterior column–medial lemniscus pathway)

  2. Ipsilateral motor weakness/paralysis
    → due to involvement of the lateral corticospinal tract

  3. Contralateral loss of:

    • Pain and temperature sensation
      → due to damage to the spinothalamic tract, which crosses 1–2 segments above its point of entry



      Other Options:

  • Dejerine syndrome: Medial medullary syndrome – contralateral hemiparesis and proprioception loss, ipsilateral tongue paralysis.

  • Weber’s syndrome: Midbrain lesion – ipsilateral oculomotor palsy with contralateral hemiparesis.

  • Wallenberg syndrome: Lateral medullary syndrome – loss of pain/temp on ipsilateral face and contralateral body, dysphagia, hoarseness.


Reference:Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no 168

questions.text: The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is?
questions.solution:
Glycine is the neurotransmitter that the Renshaw cell releases.

Negative feedback inhibition is exemplified by Renshaw cell inhibition. An inhibitory interneuron that ends on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons receives a recurrent collateral from the axon of a spinal motor neuron. Glycine is the neurotransmitter released by this inhibitory interneuron, also known as a Renshaw cell.

Glycine is released by the Renshaw cell to lower motor neuron activity.

Key points:
 
Feature Renshaw Cell
Location Anterior horn of spinal cord
Function Inhibits alpha motor neurons
Activated by Collateral from motor neuron axons
Neurotransmitter Glycine
Clinical Relevance Inhibited by tetanus toxin, leading to muscle spasms


NTs & their source:

  • Acetylcholine (ACh) – Basal nucleus of Meynert, motor neurons

  • Dopamine – Substantia nigra, ventral tegmental area

  • Norepinephrine – Locus coeruleus (pons)

  • Epinephrine – Adrenal medulla

  • Serotonin (5-HT) – Raphe nuclei (brainstem)

  • GABA – Cerebral cortex, hippocampus

  • Glycine – Spinal cord, brainstem (Renshaw cells)


Reference:Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no 128

questions.text: The following principle-' In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor' is known as ____
questions.solution:
Bell–Magendie Law:
This law states that:

  • Dorsal roots of the spinal cord carry sensory (afferent) fibers.

  • Ventral roots carry motor (efferent) fibers.
    This anatomical-functional distinction is fundamental in neurophysiology.

    Other options:
     

  • 1. Weber–Fechner law:
    Describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the stimulus (psychophysics).

  • 2. Labelled line principle:
    States that the specific pathway (line) from a receptor to the brain determines the type of sensation felt (e.g., touch vs. heat).

  • 3. Law of projection:
    Sensation is perceived at the location of the receptor, no matter where along the pathway it is stimulated (e.g., phantom limb pain).


Reference:Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no 161

questions.text: What causes a difference in the curve's trajectories for the inspiratory and expiratory loops?
questions.solution:
The curves produced during inflation and deflation show differences. Hysteresis is the name given to this variation, which is noticeably absent from the curves produced by saline. Hysteresis is influenced by the alveolar environment, particularly the produced substances that lower surface tension and prevent alveoli from collapsing.

questions.text: The chart below shows a patient's spirometry curve. Using the curve, calculate the FEV1/FVC ratio.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 80–89%

Here, we need to find FEV1 and FVC first.
FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) is the maximum amount of air that the subject can forcibly expel during the first second following maximal inhalation.
  • In the given image the interval between the two dotted lines denotes FEV1
  • FEV1 = 5000-1800 = 3200 ml
  • FVC (Forced vital capacity); the total volume of air that can be exhaled during a maximal forced expiration effort. It is total lung capacity minus the residual volume.
  • FVC = 5000-1300 = 3700
Therefore FEV1/FVC = 3200/3700 = 0.86
So, 80-89% is the correct answer.





 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 617

questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the Critical Closing volume?
questions.solution:
The closing capacity (CC) is the volume in the lungs at which its smallest airways, the respiratory bronchioles, collapse. It is defined mathematically as the sum of the closing volume and the residual volume. Option A- Volume at the end of forceful expiration is residual volume. Option B- Volume at the end of forceful inspiration is total lung capacity. Adult critical closing volume is close to residual volume. "Critical closing volume is the minimum volume and pressure of gas necessary to prevent small airway collapse. It is somewhat near to residual volume. Under pathological conditions when critical closing volume exceeds functional residual capacity, alveolar collapse occurs."

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 564

questions.text: All of the following decreases in carbon monoxide's ability to diffuse except?
questions.solution:
The diffusion capacity of CO depends upon the alveolar surface area and thickness of the alveolar membrane.

Any factor which leads to decrease in the surface area will lead to decrease in the diffusion capacity.

  • Interstitial Lung Disease
  • Emphysema

Since, in case of polycythemia, more blood cells are available for CO uptake, its diffusion capacity increases.

questions.text: Which of the following can be increased and result in a leftward shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve?
questions.solution:
Physiological factors have an effect on the oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve, resulting in a shift either to the left or the right. A leftward shift implies that a decrease in temperature, fall in blood PCO2, decrease in 2,3-DPG and rise in pH, would increase the affinity of haemoglobin to oxygen, i.e. less oxygen is released in the tissues. On the other hand, a rightward shift implies that an increase in temperature, rise in PCO2, decrease in 2,3-DPG and a fall in pH, would decrease the affinity of haemoglobin to oxygen, i.e. more oxygen would be released in the tissues. The alkalosis causes increae in H+ ions resulting in loading of oxygen and unloading of CO2 which leads to left shift of the curve.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 631

questions.text: Where is the respiratory rhythm generation center located?
questions.solution:
Prebotzinger complex. It acts as the pacemaker of respiration. 

A specialized area, called the pre-Botzinger complex (PBC), is located in the rostral part of the VRG( Ventral respiratory group) and appears to be the centre of respiratory rhythm generation.

questions.text: Chest wall and lung recoil are balanced in a relaxed condition at:
questions.solution:
FRC( functional residual capacity)

Elastic recoil is defined as the ability of a stretched or inflated Lung to return to its resting volume (FRC).

Elastic recoil of the lung is directly related to lung stiffness, that is, the stiffer the lung, the greater the elastic recoil (but lower compliance).

The lung volume at which elastic recoil of lung and elastic recoil of chest wall are at equilibrium (i.e. equal elastic recoil force but in opposite directions) is represented by FRC.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 617,619

In this case of RTA(road traffic accident)-Respiratory acidosis can be caused by depression of the respiratory center due to injury and the same accident would be causing damage to the respiratory apparatus(that is lungs/ribs/chest wall) which also would be contributing to respiratory acidosis and high arterial pCO2.

questions.text:
The value of Va / Q becomes zero when
1. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
2. No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place
3. Partial pressure of CO2 alone becomes zero
4. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 is normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place V/Q = 0 is seen in airway obstruction V/Q = ∞ is seen in blood flow obstruction The ratio of pulmonary ventilation to pulmonary blood flow for the whole lung at rest is about 0.8. If the ventilation to an alveolus is reduced relative to its perfusion, the PO2 in the alveolus falls because less O2 is delivered to it and the PCO2 rises because less CO2 is expired. Conversely, if perfusion is reduced relative to ventilation, the PCO2 falls because less CO2 is delivered and the PO2 rises because less O2 enters the blood.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 639

questions.text: The following is a crucial lung non-respiratory function of the lungs?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1. Anion balance.

The lungs play a crucial role in maintaining acid-base balance, which is related to anion balance. Specifically, the lungs help regulate the levels of bicarbonate (HCO‚ÇÉ‚Åª) and carbon dioxide (CO‚ÇÇ) in the blood. Through the process of ventilation, the lungs help remove CO‚ÇÇ, which can combine with water to form carbonic acid. This indirectly affects the balance of anions like bicarbonate.

While other balances (sodium, potassium, calcium) are primarily managed by other organs like the kidneys, the lungs have a significant impact on maintaining anion balance, especially related to the bicarbonate buffer system in the blood

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 626,641

questions.text: Identify the lipid with deficiency in a preterm baby having respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) in preterm babies is caused by a deficiency of surfactant, a complex mixture of phospholipids mainly dipalmitoyphosphatidyIcholine, proteins, neutral lipids and cholesterol. Cardiolipin (Culcutta antigens) is a phospholipid which is a component of the inner mitochondrial membrane and plays an important role in mitochondrial enzyme metabolism. Sphingomyelin are also phosphosphingolipids which are found in increased concentrations in nervous tissues, red blood cells and lens of the eyes. The lack of or insufficient surfactant production in the respiratory system of preterm babies is responsible for the alveolar collapse and leads to the onset of RDS.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 620

questions.text: Name the cell kind, baby with respiratory distress syndrome would lack with
questions.solution:
Alveolar capillary endothelial cells are part of the capillary wall that lines the inner surface of the vasculature. These cells help to maintain hemostasis by preventing the coagulation of the blood and ensuring that all blood flows smoothly through the capillaries. Type I alveolar cells form part of the air-blood barrier, and they are involved in the process of gas exchange between the alveoli and the blood. Type 2 cells contain secretory organelles known as lamellar bodies, which are responsible for the release of pulmonary surfactant. Alveolar macrophages are a type of immune cells that are responsible for clearing the air space. They can remove any infectious, toxic, or allergic particles, as well as secreting interleukin 4 and 10 to control any risk of uncontrolled inflammation.

Thus, a lack of Type 2 alveolar cells would lead to Respiratory Distress Syndrome in a newborn baby. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 611

questions.text:
What does it mean when it VA/Q is ∞
1. Partial pressure of alveolar gas is same as dead space
2. The pO2 of alveolar air is 159 mm Hg and PCO2 is 40 mm Hg
3. Partial pressure of O2 and CO2 are equal
4. No diffusion of O2 from alveoli to blood and CO2 from blood to alveolar gas
questions.solution:
VA/Q is a ratio used to describe the proportion of ventilation (V) to perfusion (Q) of air in the lungs. When no exchange of CO2 and O2 occurs, VA/Q is at infinity because there is no air moving between the two processes. In this case, the VA/Q ratio would be infinite because there is no exchange of gasses between the alveoli and pulmonary capillaries, causing infinite ventilation for every unit of perfusion (Q).

Statement 1 is also correct since if there is no perfusion then there is no gas exchange hence the partial pressure of the alveoli will be same as that of dead space.

This is a highly controversial question but option 4 seems the better answer.
 

Reference :Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition page no 525

questions.text: PaO2 (Arterial) is not decreased in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Congestive heart failure without Pulmonary edema
  • The partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is a measure of the amount of oxygen dissolved in the blood.
  • The question asks which of the given conditions does not cause a decrease in PaO2. Option 2, congestive heart failure, is the correct answer. In congestive heart failure, the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. This can lead to fluid buildup in the lungs, causing shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. However, it does not directly affect the amount of oxygen in the blood, and therefore does not cause a decrease in PaO2.
  • Option 1, restrictive lung disease, refers to a group of lung diseases that restrict lung expansion, making it difficult to breathe. This can lead to a decrease in PaO2 due to reduced oxygen exchange in the lungs.
  • Option 3, obstructive lung disease, refers to a group of lung diseases that obstruct airflow, making it difficult to exhale. This can lead to a decrease in PaO2 due to reduced oxygen exchange in the lungs.
  • Option 4, high altitude, refers to a condition where there is a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen due to lower atmospheric pressure at high altitudes. This can lead to a decrease in PaO2 due to reduced oxygen availability.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545153/

choices.text: Binding of Oxygen to Hb makes it more acidic
Decrease in blood pH results in a lower affinity of Hb for oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Haldane Effect is not true?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2:Binding of Oxygen to Hb makes it more acidic.
The Haldane Effect describes the phenomenon where the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin (Hb) in the lungs promotes the release of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the blood into the lungs, while the release of oxygen from Hb in the tissues promotes the uptake of CO2 from the tissues into the blood.
This effect is due to the fact that oxygenated Hb has a lower affinity for CO2 and protons than deoxygenated Hb.
Option 2 is false because the binding of oxygen to Hb actually makes it less acidic, not more acidic. When oxygen binds to Hb, it forms oxyhemoglobin (HbO2), which is a stronger acid acceptor than deoxygenated Hb. This means that HbO2 can buffer excess protons in the blood, which reduces the acidity of the blood.

Option 4 is true because :A decrease in blood pH, which indicates an increase in acidity, actually results in a decrease affinity of Hb for oxygen.This is known as the Bohr Effect, which describes how the binding of protons (H+) to Hb in the tissues promotes the release of oxygen from Hb to the tissues. 

Option 1 is true because the binding of oxygen to Hb reduces its affinity for CO2, as mentioned above.

Option 3 is true because deoxygenated Hb has a higher affinity for protons than oxygenated Hb, so it binds more H+ ions in the tissues.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 631,632

questions.text: Which of the following effects is governed by the Gibbs-Donnan effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Chloride shift
 
  • HCO3-/Cl- transporter is present on the RBC membrane. It allows the bicarbonate ions to diffuse out of the RBC into the plasma and in exchange the chloride ions diffuse into the RBC via facilitated diffusion counter transport. This is known as HAMBURGER PHENOMENON OR CHLORIDE SHIFT.
  • The Chloride Shift is governed by the Gibbs–Donnan effect  which describes the behaviour of charged particles across a semipermeable membrane.   
  • The Gibbs–Donnan theory describes the equilibrium conditions for ions separated by a  semipermeable  membrane when  the presence of non permeating particles ( like Proteins ) distorts the distribution of permeating ions on the two sides of the semi permeable membrane.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 8,9

questions.text: Why do small airways have laminar air flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Extremely low velocity

Flow can be of 2 types :- 1) TURBULENT
                                           2) LAMINAR
  • LAMINAR FLOW –  Laminar flow is orderly and has low resistance 
  • TURBULENT FLOW – Turbulent flow is disorganized and has high resistance.
The air flow is the same for all cross-sections.  But the linear velocity of the gas is air flow divided by the cross-sectional area , therefore gas velocity is much less in the small airways. As a result, small airways have fully developed laminar flow.

In small airways, the air velocity is very low due to the small cross-sectional area and the longer length of the airways.
This low velocity leads to the development of laminar flow in the small airways.
The Reynolds number is a dimensionless quantity that describes the transition from laminar to turbulent flow in a fluid.
For air flowing through small airways, the Reynolds number is typically less than 2000, indicating laminar flow. 
Option 2, "Very small diameter," may contribute to laminar flow, but it is not the primary reason for it. The low velocity of air is the main factor that leads to laminar flow in small airways.
Option 4, "Low cross-sectional area," is related to the low velocity of air, but it is not the reason for laminar flow. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 562

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true for a man connected to a body plethysmograph for estimation of FRC inspires against a closed glottis
questions.solution:
• When a person inspires against a closed glottis while connected to a body plethysmograph for the estimation of functional residual capacity (FRC), the pressure in the lungs decreases, but the pressure in the box increases. This is because when the person inspires against a closed glottis, the air cannot escape from the lungs, which causes the volume of air in the lungs to increase. As a result, the pressure in the lungs decreases.
  • On the other hand, the volume of air in the box remains constant, but the pressure in the box increases due to the increase in the volume of the lungs.
  • Therefore, option 3 is correct. To explain this phenomenon, we can use Boyle's law, which states that the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume at a constant temperature. When a person inspires against a closed glottis, the volume of air in the lungs increases, which causes the pressure in the lungs to decrease.
  • At the same time, the volume of air in the box remains constant, but the pressure in the box increases due to the increase in the volume of the lungs.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK500007/

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Warburg effect?
questions.solution:
Warburg effect is a phenomenon characterized by increased rate of glucose uptake and conversion into lactose even in the presence of oxygen. 

Even though Warburg effect generates only 2 molecules of ATP, it leaves behind adequate carbon moieties which can be used as building blocks for lipids and proteins. 

Oxidative phosphorylation on the other hand leaves behind no carbon moieties as glucose is entirely converted to CO2 and H2O. 

This property of cancer cells of glucose hunger ( Warburg Effect ) is used to visualize them via positron emission tomography ( PET ) scanning. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 299, 300.

choices.text: Decreasing ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains
Binds to the central cavity of Hb surrounded by Histidine and Lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.text: 2,3, BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues by?
questions.solution:
• 2,3-BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues by binding to the central cavity of Hb surrounded by Histidine & lysine & favors salt bridge formation
 

  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) is a key regulator of oxygen delivery by hemoglobin (Hb). It binds to the central cavity of deoxyhemoglobin (taut or T-state) through interactions with positively charged residues, primarily histidine and lysine.

    This binding stabilizes the T-state of hemoglobin, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby facilitating oxygen release (unloading) to the tissues. The presence of 2,3-BPG shifts the oxygen dissociation curve of hemoglobin to the right, meaning more oxygen is released at a given partial pressure.



Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 630-632.

questions.text: The blue curve 'X' in the picture below depicts:
questions.solution:
Blue curve 'X' (Rectilinear Hyperbola) is due to myoglobin.
Since 1 myoglobin binds 1 molecule of O2 the shape is not sigmoid.
 

  1. Hyperbolic Shape:

    • The curve is steep, indicating that myoglobin binds to oxygen with high affinity, even at relatively low oxygen concentrations.
    • This high affinity means that once myoglobin binds to oxygen, it holds onto it strongly.

  2. Oxygen Affinity:

    • Myoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen compared to hemoglobin. This allows it to effectively pick up oxygen from hemoglobin in the muscle tissue and store it for use during periods of low oxygen availability (e.g., during exercise).

  3. Saturation:

    • Myoglobin is almost fully saturated with oxygen at normal physiological partial pressures of oxygen (around 20–40 mmHg). This makes it efficient for oxygen storage in muscle tissue.
    • It does not exhibit the cooperative binding behavior seen in hemoglobin, meaning each molecule binds oxygen independently without affecting others.

  4. P50 (Partial Pressure of Oxygen at 50% Saturation):

    • The P50 for myoglobin is low (around 2–3 mmHg), which means it will become 50% saturated at a low oxygen pressure. In comparison, hemoglobin’s P50 is around 26 mmHg.


Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 548, 631, 632, 640, 641.

questions.text: Least A-V difference is seen in?
questions.solution:
• The correct option is 3. Kidney.
 
  • The A-V difference refers to the difference in oxygen concentration between arterial (A) blood and venous (V) blood. The A-V difference is a measure of how much oxygen is extracted from the blood by the tissues. The greater the A-V difference, the more oxygen is extracted by the tissues.
 
  • The kidney has the least A-V difference among the options given. This is because the kidney requires a constant supply of blood to maintain its metabolic processes, and it extracts only a small amount of oxygen from the blood.
 
  • The brain and liver have a higher A-V difference because they require more oxygen for their metabolic processes.
 
  • The skin also has a higher A-V difference because it plays a role in temperature regulation, which requires significant oxygen consumption.



Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 590, 666.

questions.text: 2,3-BPG decrease the affinity of Hb to oxygen by binding to which chain?
questions.solution:
• 2,3-DPG acts as an allosteric regulator of hemoglobin in the RBC. When 2,3-DPG is bound to beta chains of hemoglobin, it stabilizes the T-state conformation and decreases hemoglobin affinity for oxygen.
 
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) binds to the beta chains of deoxyhemoglobin (the T-state of hemoglobin). This binding stabilizes the T-state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thus promoting oxygen release in tissues.
 
  • 2,3-BPG does not bind to the alpha chains but rather to the positively charged residues in the central cavity of the hemoglobin tetramer, which is primarily formed by the beta chains. This decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen and facilitates oxygen unloading in peripheral tissues.



Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 630-632.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Hypothermia is not a cause of cyanosis.

Cyanosis is a bluish discoloration of the skin, lips, or mucous membranes caused by the presence of deoxygenated hemoglobin(>5g/dL) in the blood vessels near the skin surface. It can be caused by various conditions that result in reduced oxygen levels in the blood.

  • Pulmonary arteriovenous fistula is a rare condition where there is an abnormal connection between an artery and vein in the lung. This can result in a decrease in oxygen levels in the blood, leading to cyanosis.
  • Methemoglobinemia is a condition where there is an increased level of methemoglobin, which is an abnormal form of hemoglobin that cannot bind to oxygen effectively. This can result in a decrease in oxygen levels in the blood and lead to cyanosis.
  • High altitude can cause cyanosis due to decreased oxygen availability at higher altitudes, which can lead to reduced oxygen levels in the blood.
  • Hypothermia is a condition where the body temperature drops below normal levels. It can cause various symptoms, including pale or blue skin, but this is not true cyanosis caused by deoxygenated hemoglobin.

Therefore, the answer is option 4, hypothermia.
 

Reference : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 247 .

questions.text: In the absence of surfactant, which of the following is seen?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Surface tension increases, compliance decreases

Surfactant decreases the surface tension of the fluid interface.
  • An important factor affecting the compliance of the lungs is the surface tension of the film of fluid that lines the alveoli. 
  • A deficiency of surfactant would lead to increased surface tension (due to the absence of the tension-lowering effect of the surfactant), which would lead to decreased compliance.

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions and was diagnosed as a case of RDS. What is most likely deficient in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Lecithin

Deficiency of mature surfactant leads to RDS.

  • Lecithin (DPPC) constitutes 90% of surfactant composition.
  • Surfactant deficiency (decreased production and secretion) is the primary cause of RDS.
  • The failure to attain an adequate FRC and the tendency of affected lungs to become atelectatic correlate with high surface tension and the absence of pulmonary surfactant.
  • The major constituents of surfactant are dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (lecithin), phosphatidylglycerol, apoproteins (surfactant proteins SP-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D), and cholesterol.
  • Surfactant is present in high concentrations in fetal lung homogenates by 20 wk of gestation, but it does not reach the surface of the lungs until later. It appears in amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 wk of gestation. Mature levels of pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 wk of gestation.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No- 850.

questions.text: At which volume or capacity, pressure measured at the upper airway becomes zero?
questions.solution:
At functional residual capacity (FRC), the pressure measured in the upper airway drops to zero.

The pressure-volume curve, which plots airway pressure against lung volume, helps us understand how the lungs and chest wall work together. This curve shows the relationship between lung compliance and chest wall compliance and is measured using a spirometer.

Functional residual capacity is the amount of air left in the lungs after a normal exhalation, usually around 2.5 liters. When the lungs are at this volume, they are in a relaxed state, and the pressure inside the lungs is effectively zero.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: The type of hypoxia based on the graph is-
questions.solution:
The graph illustrates the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve comparing anemic hypoxia with normal conditions. The X-axis represents the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2), while the Y-axis shows the percentage saturation between hemoglobin and oxygen.

There are two lines on the graph: a dotted line representing normal hemoglobin levels and a solid line for reduced hemoglobin levels. The dotted line indicates arterial blood oxygen content of around 19 mL/dL and venous blood oxygen content of 14 mL/dL. In contrast, the solid line reflects an arterial oxygen content of 9 mL/dL and venous oxygen content of 4 mL/dL.

This situation highlights a 50% reduction in hemoglobin's oxygen saturation, even though the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) remains normal. This condition is known as anemic hypoxia.

In anemic hypoxia, the blood's oxygen content is reduced. Patients may not experience issues at rest due to an increase in 2,3-DPG within red blood cells. However, during physical activity, they may struggle because of a limited ability to increase oxygen delivery (QO) to active tissues.

Factors that cause a rightward shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (seen in metabolically active tissues with increased oxygen demand) include:

- Hypoxia
- Hypercarbia
- Decreased pH
- Increased temperature
- Increased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG)

Factors that cause a leftward shift in the curve include:

- Increased oxygen
- Decreased carbon dioxide
- Increased pH
- Decreased temperature
- Decreased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG)
- Fetalhemoglobin.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 638,639 .

questions.text: A new resident to a high-altitude area develops hypoxia. What is the causative factor?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia at high altitudes is caused by the low partial pressure of oxygen (O2), which affects oxygen availability for bodily functions.

Adaptation to High Altitudes:
Work capacity decreases as oxygen uptake diminishes with increasing altitude, leading to reduced physical performance.

Immediate adaptation: The body responds to the reduced oxygen levels at higher altitudes by stimulating arterial chemoreceptors, leading to increased alveolar ventilation. This increase in breathing rates expels more carbon dioxide (CO2), causing a drop in PCO2 and inducing respiratory alkalosis (increased blood pH).

Respiratory alkalosis: The elevated pH due to reduced CO2 levels inhibits the brain's respiratory centers, reducing the drive to breathe and limiting the body's ability to maximize oxygen intake. This effect can hinder physical performance, especially during strenuous activities.

Kidney compensation: The kidneys respond by decreasing hydrogen ion secretion and increasing bicarbonate excretion, lowering plasma and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) bicarbonate levels. This correction helps restore normal pH, removing the inhibitory effects of alkalosis on respiration, which in turn allows for more effective ventilation and improved exercise capacity.

Lactic acid accumulation: At high altitudes, the lack of sufficient oxygen causes pyruvic acid, formed during glycolysis, to be converted into lactic acid, which accumulates in the muscles and bloodstream. This increase in lactic acid contributes to extreme fatigue, making physical exertion more difficult.

questions.text: In the following graph showing left ventricular pressure volume loop, which of the following corresponds to the v wave of JVP
questions.solution:
In the given pressure volume loop point D to Point A corresponds to isometric relaxation which corresponds to v wave on the JVP.
The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:
• a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
• c wave represents iso-volumetric contraction occurring in ventricular systole.
• x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
• v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
• y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole.




Ref: Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition • Page no 531

questions.text: 2 medical students are conducting a study to see the effects of acclimatization at high altitudes. Which of the following will not be seen in the same?
questions.solution:
When someone ascends to high altitude, the atmospheric oxygen pressure (pO‚ÇÇ) drops, leading to hypoxia. The body responds with a series of acclimatization changes to improve oxygen delivery:
 
  1. Increased Hemoglobin (Hb): Hypoxia stimulates erythropoietin (EPO) from the kidneys, leads to polycythemia
  2. Increased Myoglobin (in muscle tissues): to improve oxygen storage and delivery in skeletal muscles
  3. Increased Ventilation (Hyperventilation): Immediate response to hypoxia is hyperventilation (low oxygen (PO2) cause arterial chemoreceptor activation and leads to an increase in alveolar ventilation). Helps raise alveolar pO‚ÇÇ. Hyperventilation causes respiratory alkalosis, which is later compensated by renal bicarbonate loss.
  4. Increased 2,3-BPG: Shifts oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the right for improved oxygen unloading at tissues.

Reference: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, pp. 554-555.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will shift the Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the left?
questions.solution:
A leftward shift of the Oxygen–Hemoglobin dissociation curve means increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen — making it harder to release oxygen to the tissues.

Conditions that shift the curve to the left (↑ O‚ÇÇ affinity):

  • Alkalosis (↑ pH)

  • Hypocarbia (↓ CO‚ÇÇ)

  • ↓ Temperature

  • ↓ 2,3-DPG

  • Fetal hemoglobin (HbF)

  • Carbon monoxide poisoning

Mnemonic: "CADET, face Left!"
(CO‚ÇÇ ↓, Acidity ↓, DPG ↓, Exercise ↓, Temperature ↓)

Incorrect Options:

  • Hypercarbia: ↑ CO‚ÇÇ → right shift

  • ↑ 2,3-DPG: → right shift

  • Hypoxia: → promotes right shift (to release more O‚ÇÇ to tissues)


Reference: Ganongs review of medical physiology 25th edition page no 631-633

questions.text: Which is the reflex that causes tachycardia when the right atrium is distended?

A tiny portion of this increase is due to the stretched sinus node as a direct result of the increased atrial volume; this direct stretch can raise heart rate by as much as 15%.

questions.text: A newborn displays all of the following responses to cold, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Neonates lack the shivering mechanism because they do not have enough body fat or muscle mass to generate the heat needed to maintain body temperature. Shivering is an involuntary response triggered by cold temperatures, which causes the body to vibrate and produce heat. Neonates' lack of body fat and muscle mass make it difficult for them to generate enough body heat to maintain their body temperatures in cold environments.

questions.text: What happens to the blood flow to the brain during light exercise?
questions.solution:
When engaging in physical activity, the body shifts how much blood is routed to various parts. The amount of blood sent to the heart and muscles after moderate to heavy workout increases, whereas the quantity flowing to the liver, kidneys, and internal organs is decreased. However, during light exercise, there is no significant change in blood flow to the brain due to autoregulation. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 539

questions.text: Where does ventricular depolarization start?
questions.solution:
Ventricular depolarization starts from the left part of the interventricular septum due to the presence of the specialized conduction system in the heart. This specialized conduction system includes the sinoatrial (SA) node, atrioventricular (AV) node, bundle of His, and Purkinje fibers.

The electrical impulse starts with the SA node and travels through the atria causing them to contract. The electrical impulse then reaches the AV node and spreads to the bundle of His and into the right and left bundle branches.

The electrical impulse then divides and travels down the Purkinje fibers, which are located on the interior wall of the ventricles, causing them to depolarize and contract.

These fibers on the left side of the interventricular septum have a slightly faster conduction velocity and therefore start the ventricular depolarization from the left part of the interventricular septum.

Remember- The sequence of depolarization of heart is endocardium-myocardium-epicardium.

The sequence of repolarization of heart is epicardium-myocardium-endocardium whereas the sequence in an isolated cardiac myocyte is endocardium-myocardium-epicardium.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529

questions.text: The inward flow pressure in the provided circuit is 100 mm Hg, while the outward flow pressure is 10 mm Hg. The resistance in each parallel circuit is 5 mm Hg/mL/min. How much current will flow via the circuit?
questions.solution:
In fluid mechanics,                                                                 
The hydraulic resistance, R is defined as the ratio of pressure drop, Pi- Po, to flow, Q. Pi is the pressure at inflow
Po is the pressure at outflow
Thus, R = (Pi -Po)/Q
Given each circuit has resistance = 5 mm Hg/mL/min.
Also for resistance in parallel
1/net resistance = 1/r1 + 1/r2 ………1/rn
Thus net resistance in the given question = 1 mm hg/ml min
Hence, by calculation for flow using ohms law, we get
Flow, Q = (100-90)/1 = 90 ml/min.


Reference: https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/resistor/res_4.html

questions.text: Which of the following defines vascular system pressure in the absence of blood flow?
questions.solution:
Equilibrium pressure in the absence of flow pressure is called Mean circulatory filling pressure and is exerted by the blood volume on the whole cardiovascular circuit. When the heart is stopped, either through electrical shock or any other method, circulation ceases almost immediately and the pressures across the body become equal. This pressure is known as the mean circulatory filling pressure.


Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8458763/

questions.text: Which of the following statements about blood pressure measurement is correct?
questions.solution:
Following are the initial steps of BP measurement outlining the question.
a. Have the patient rest for at least 5 minutes and for 30 or more minutes after drinking coffee or smoking.
b. It is best to take readings for both arms, as the higher of the two is normally closest to the aortic pressure and is thus used to decide on treatment.
c. While the patient is either standing or seated comfortably, make sure to have the arm be placed at a heart level position with no tight clothing on the upper arm. It is also fine to measure by leaving thin clothing on.
d. The usual Riva-Rocci cuff should be 12.5 cm wide and 30-35 cm long. Make sure to have the center of the cuff fit around at least 80% of the circumference of the arm. Place the cuff over the brachial artery.

Option 4 is also false as blood pressure decreases during sleep.

questions.text: Which cells of the human body are most sensitive to ischemia?
questions.solution:
Neurons are the cells of the human body that are most sensitive to ischemia, which refers to a lack of oxygen and nutrients due to decreased blood flow to a particular tissue or organ. Neurons require a constant supply of oxygen and glucose to function properly, and even a brief interruption of blood flow can cause irreversible damage. Other cells, such as nephrons in the kidneys, cardiac myocytes in the heart, and hepatocytes in the liver, are also sensitive to ischemia, but neurons are the most vulnerable

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 134

questions.text: Which is the best index to measure cardiac afterload?
questions.solution:

questions.text: What are the characteristics of neurogenic shock?
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock: In addition to arteriolar dilation, venodilation causes pooling in the venous system, which decreases venous return and cardiac output." Interruption of sympathetic vasomotor input after a high cervical spinal cord injury, inadvertent cephalad migration of spinal anesthesia, or devastating head injury may result in neurogenic shock. The extremities are often warm, in contrast to the usual sympathetic vasoconstriction-induced coolness in hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock

questions.text: The JVP waveform is used to assess the status of the right side of the heart and is helpful in diagnosing various cardiovascular conditions. When are C waves in JVP visible?
questions.solution:
When observing the JVP waveform, there are several waves and descents that can be identified: A wave (Atrial contraction): This is the first positive wave seen in the JVP waveform. It corresponds to atrial contraction, which occurs just before ventricular systole (contraction). The A wave reflects the increased pressure caused by blood flowing into the right atrium during atrial contraction. X descent (Atrial relaxation): After the A wave, there is a downward descent known as the X descent. This descent is caused by the relaxation of the right atrium, which results in decreased pressure in the jugular vein. C wave (Isovolumic ventricular contraction): The C wave is a small upward deflection that occurs shortly after the A wave. It represents a slight increase in pressure in the right atrium caused by the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium during isovolumic ventricular contraction. X' descent (Ventricular ejection): Following the C wave, there is a rapid descent known as the X' descent. It is caused by the downward movement of the tricuspid valve as the right ventricle contracts and ejects blood into the pulmonary artery. V wave (Venous filling): The V wave is a large positive wave that occurs after the X' descent. It represents the filling of blood into the right atrium from the peripheral veins during systole. The V wave is often prominent in conditions such as tricuspid regurgitation or right-sided heart failure. Y descent (Rapid ventricular filling): The Y descent is a downward slope that follows the V wave. It represents the rapid ventricular filling phase, during which the tricuspid valve opens and blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: There is a______in hypovolemic shock.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Afferent arteriolar constriction In hypovolemic shock, the body compensates for volume loss by increasing heart rate and contractility, followed by baroreceptor activation resulting in sympathetic nervous system activation and peripheral vasoconstriction. Thus renal blood flow and gfr also decreases. Afferent arteriolar constriction —> decreased gfr —> less fluid loss in urine.This way the blood is shunted towards the heart in c/o shock. Options 2 and 3 are incorrect as efferent arteriolar constriction will result into increased gfr and loss of fluid furthermore. Renal blood flow is decrease and not increased by peripheral vasoconstriction. Option 4 : as effective circulating blood volume is reduced, CO also decreases. Grading of Hypovolemic Shock

 

Reference-:Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 27th Edition Page nos 13,14

questions.text: During vigorous exercise, pulmonary arterial pressure barely rises but cardiac output (CO) increases up to fivefold. The best explanation for this physiological property of the pulmonary circulation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increase in the number of open capillaries During exercise the demand for O2 increases drastically. By opening more capillaries, the surface area available for gas exchange increases, allowing for a greater amount of oxygen to be taken up from the alveoli into the blood and a larger amount of carbon dioxide to be released from the blood into the alveoli for exhalation. Option 2 - Sympathetic activation can cause vasoconstriction in systemic circulation to redirect blood flow to the working muscles during exercise, but it does not play a significant role in regulating pulmonary vascular resistance. Option 3 – large amount of smooth muscles can constrict or dilate the arteries up to some extent but it’s not the primary mechanism. Option 4 – it is incorrect as the surface area for pulmonary circulation is actually very large.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 615,616

choices.text: Bulging of tricuspid valve during the isovolumetric contraction phase

questions.text: JVP with C wave is due to
questions.solution:
The C wave of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is created by the bulging of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole, when the right ventricle contracts. As the right ventricle contracts, the tricuspid valve is forced open, allowing the blood to flow through the tricuspid valve into the right atrium. The increase in pressure in the right atrium causes the jugular vein to bulge and create the C wave of the JVP.

The jugular venous pulse (JVP) is observed to look different due to factors such as changes in the heart rate, respiratory rate, and intrathoracic pressure. Waves in the JVP include the a wave, c wave, v wave, and x and y descents. The a wave is caused by right atrial contraction, the c wave is related to the bulging of the tricuspid valve, the v wave is related to filling of the right atrium, and the x and y descents are attributed to the relaxation of the right atrium/tricuspid valve.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: During an experiment, a scientist detected bradycardia and hypotension. This could be because of:
questions.solution:
1. Bezold-Jarisch reflex- significant bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by fast shallow breathing when chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) are activated. Numerous chemicals, such as capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine, can cause this reflex.

Cushing's Reaction- is a specific kind of CNS ischemic response that happens when the CSF pressure is very high causing an increase in arterial pressure.

Bainbridge Reflex- an atrial reflex that controls heart rate. An increase in atrial pressure causes an increase in heart rate. 

 

Peripheral chemoreceptor reflex- Chemoreceptors primarily influence respiration, although their activation also causes vasoconstriction.

questions.text:
What will be the sequence after the P wave

A. a wave
B. 1st heart sound
C. Filling of ventricles
D. T wave
questions.solution:
The correct sequence on cardiac cycle is  3. A -> C -> B - > D. 
Amongst given option correct answer would be a wave ->Ventricular filling ->1st heart sound ->T wave
 

  • A wave: After the P wave, the a wave on JVP occurs, which represents atrial contraction. This follows the depolarization of the atria (P wave), leading to the contraction of the atria and the push of blood into the ventricles.

  • Filling of ventricles: After the a wave, the ventricles fill with blood following the atrial contraction.(NOTE: 70% of ventricular filling is passive - only about 30% is due to atrial contraction)

  • 1st heart sound (S1): The first heart sound (S1) occurs when the AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) close, signaling the beginning of ventricular systole.

  • T wave: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and occurs much later, after the ventricular contraction (systole) has finished.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529,530

questions.text: What happens when a person changes posture from supine to standing?
questions.solution:

This cascade continues and the decrease in cardiac output causes a similar decrease in blood pressure which leads to decreased firing from Baroreceptors.

1st heart sound- A-V Valves closing.

2nd heart sound- closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves.

3rd Heart Sound- begins at the start of the Middle Third of the Diastole and is caused by blood oscillating back and forth between the walls of the ventricles, which is caused by blood pouring in from the atria.

questions.text: A patient complains of breathing difficulties and widespread weakness. A mid-diastolic murmur with pronounced "a" waves is audible on auscultation in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: TS (Tricuspid stenosis)

The symptoms given such as breathing difficulty and weakness along with a mid diastolic murmur with pronounced “a” waves is definitive of TS.
  • The narrowing of the tricuspid valve impedes blood flow, leading to several symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath (especially during physical activity), palpitations, abdominal discomfort, and edema. In severe cases, tricuspid stenosis can cause heart failure.
  • A mid diastolic murmur is a characteristic feature of mitral stenosis but is seen in both mitral as well as tricuspid stenosis.
  • MDM + dyspnea suggests left sided defect like MS
MDM + edema suggests Right sided defect like TS
  • In this case, even though patient is presenting with MDM + dyspnea, a classical prominent “a” wave is seen on jvp which strongly suggests TS as the right answer.
A small table to remember in valvular heart diseases is as follows-

questions.text: What is the reason of the dicrotic notch on the aortic pressure curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Closure of the aortic valve
  • The Dicrotic Notch occurs due to pressure changes caused by the closure of the Aortic Valve.
  •  The aortic valve opens during systole to allow blood to be ejected from the left ventricle into the aorta.
  • Once the left ventricle has finished contracting, the pressure in the aorta begins to fall as blood flows out into the systemic circulation.
  • As the pressure in the aorta falls, the aortic valve begins to close, causing a brief increase in pressure known as the dicrotic notch.
  • This notch is followed by a second, smaller rise in pressure as the aortic valve closes completely, preventing blood from flowing back into the left ventricle.
  • he closure of the aortic valve is essential for maintaining forward blood flow and preventing backflow into the left ventricle.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529

questions.text: Which of the following periods of the cardiac cycle sees the greatest blood flow into the ventricle?
questions.solution:
Option 2, Atrial diastole, is the correct answer.
  • Option 2, Atrial diastole, is correct because during this period, the atria are relaxed and filling with blood from the veins.
  • As the atria fill, the pressure inside them increases, causing the AV valves to open and blood to flow into the ventricles.
  • This is known as the passive filling phase, and it accounts for the majority of the blood flow into the ventricles.
  • During atrial systole, the atria contract to push any remaining blood into the ventricles, but this contributes only a small amount of additional blood flow.
  • During ventricular systole, the ventricles contract to pump blood out of the heart, and during isovolumic contraction, the ventricles are contracting but not yet pushing blood out, so there is no additional blood flow into the ventricles during these periods. 
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529

questions.text: What is the cause of the heart's elasticity?
questions.solution:

  • The elasticity of the heart muscle is  determined by a protein called Titin.
  • Titin is  responsible for elastic recoil of the cardiac myocyte, which contributes to the diastolic function which is an important mechanism of left ventricular (LV) filling. It also makes a major contribution to the diastolic wall stress of the LV .
  •  In heart failure, the titin is less stiff and becomes a bigger protein.
  • VERY IMP:- TITIN GENE MUTATION – ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT CAUSE OF DILATED CARDIOMYOPATHY
 

Reference- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 79

questions.text: What does -30 to -60 degree axis deviation indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct option 1: Left Axis Deviation (LAD).
  • The normal cardiac axis, which represents the overall direction of electrical activity in the heart, ranges from -30 to +90 degrees.
  • LAD is diagnosed when the QRS complex in lead I is mostly negative and mostly positive in lead aVF.
  • This suggests that the electrical activity in the heart is directed towards the left side of the body, which can be caused by conditions such as left ventricular hypertrophy, conduction abnormalities, or myocardial infarction.
  • It is important to note that LAD can also be a normal variant in some individuals.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 516

questions.text: What kind of mechanism is involved in Baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
Baroreceptor is an example of negative feedback mechanism.

Option A- Feedforward mechanism responds to anticipation of a change of regulated variable. Example- Increased secretion of insulin when meal reaches digestive tract.

Option C- Positive feedback mechanism refers to enhancement of amplification of the output which moves in the direction of the initial change. Eg- LH surge which is positively regulated by estrogen. 



Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 576-579.

questions.text:
Regarding the cardiac action potential, which of the following is correct?

1. The slope of Phase 1 is due to the opening of Na+ channels.
2. The slope of Phase 2 is due to the opening of Ca+2 channels.
3. The slope of Phase 3 is due to the closure  of Na+ channels and opening of K+ channels.
4. The slope of Phase 4 is due to the overactivity of Na+/K+ pump.
questions.solution:
Answer: (2)  The slope of Phase 2 is due to the opening of Ca+2 channels.

  • The transmembrane action potential of single cardiac muscle cells is characterized by rapid depolarization (phase 0), an initial rapid repolarization (phase 1), a plateau (phase 2), and a slow repolarization process (phase 3) that allows return to the resting membrane potential (phase 4).
  • The initial depolarization is due to Na+ influx through rapidly opening Na+ channels (the Na+ current, INa).
  • The inactivation of Na+ channels contributes to the rapid repolarization phase. Ca2+ influx through more slowly opening Ca2+ channels (the Ca2+ current, I Ca) produces the plateau phase, and repolarization is due to net K+ efflux through multiple types of K+ channels.
  • Recorded extracellularly, the summed electrical activity of all the cardiac muscle fibers is the ECG.




Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 520.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a property of ventricular cardiac muscle?
questions.solution:
• Due to the property of a long refractory period among cardiac muscles, the cardiac muscles cannot be tetanized.
  • Other properties of ventricular cardiac muscle include all or none phenomenon, length tension relationship.


Phases of cardiac action potential
‚óè 0→ Depolarisation and overshoot-Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels
‚óè 1→ Initial rapid repolarization-Due to closure of Na+ channels and opening up of K+ channels
‚óè 2→ Plateau phase - Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
‚óè 3→ Late rapid repolarization
‚óè 4→ Baseline (RMP).

Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux through K+ channels.
During phases 0 to 2 and about half of phase 3 of cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 112-115.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is secreted by the SA node in response to increased blood pressure?

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for fetal heart acceleration?
questions.solution:
• Amongst the given options, the best answer for the site responsible for Fetal heart acceleration is Carotid body chemoreceptors>Aortic baroreceptors>Autonomic brain stem regulation.
 
  • Though the brainstem is critical to mediating this reflex, the primary stimulus for initiating the changes in the heart rate is initiated by the carotid chemo and baro receptors, especially the chemoreceptor which is highly sensitive to the changes in O02 levels in the blood. It plays a permissive role on fetal heart rate acceleration.
 
  • Arterial chemoreceptors in the carotid arteries>aortic arch, respond to low pH levels and decreased oxygen saturation. These chemoreceptors detect instances of significant fall in blood oxygen levels, setting off the peripheral chemoreflex and heightening both parasympathetic and sympathetic neural activities.
  • The activation of the parasympathetic branch leads to a swift decline in Fetal Heart Rate (FHR), a clinical manifestation identified as intrapartum decelerations. Concurrently, the sympathetic branch prompts significant peripheral vasoconstriction across a range of vascular territories, which results in the elevation of arterial blood pressure, ensuring continuous perfusion to essential organs.
 
  • The permissive action on the FHR acceleration comes in instances of alleviated hypoxemia, detected by the chemoreceptors in the carotid body and aortic arch, suppressing the peripheral chemoreflex, leading to a reduction in parasympathetic and sympathetic neural activities.
  • Deactivation of the parasympathetic branch results in a swift increase in Fetal Heart Rate (FHR), typically seen clinically as an increase in intrapartum accelerations.



Reference: Armstrong M, Kerndt CC, Moore RA. Physiology, Baroreceptors. [Updated 2023 Mar 6]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538172/

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure.

questions.text: Increase in blood pressure at the beginning of valsalvamaneuver is due to-
questions.solution:
The initial rise in blood pressure during the Valsalva maneuver is due to the increased intrathoracic pressure, which adds to the aortic pressure. The Valsalva maneuver involves forceful expiration against a closed glottis, commonly occurring during actions like coughing, defecation, and heavy lifting. At the start of straining, blood pressure increases because the elevated intrathoracic pressure adds to the pressure in the aorta. However, the pressure then drops as the high intrathoracic pressure compresses the veins, reducing cardiac output.

When the glottis opens and intrathoracic pressure returns to normal, cardiac output is restored. However, peripheral blood vessels constrict, causing a temporary rise in blood pressure above normal levels. This activates the baroreceptors, leading to bradycardia and a subsequent decrease in blood pressure back to normal.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 580,581 .

questions.text: Windkessel effect is shown by all except-
questions.solution:
The Windkessel effect is observed in all arteries except the radial artery.

This effect is prominent in large elastic arteries such as the aorta, carotid, and renal arteries. The elasticity, or Windkessel effect, is a unique characteristic of large, elastic vessels. When these vessels are stretched, they undergo elastic recoil. During systole, the aorta expands, temporarily storing blood and allowing more to enter. This stored blood is then released during diastole, ensuring continuous organ perfusion even when the heart is at rest.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1381 .

questions.text: The first heart sound coincides with which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of systole, which marks the start of Isovolumetric contraction phase.

  • During this phase, the ventricles begin to contract.

  • All heart valves (AV and semilunar) are closed.

  • Pressure rises rapidly in the ventricles but no blood is ejected yet, thus the volume remains constant.


The relationship between Heart sounds with the phases of cardiac cycle has been summarized in the table below:



WIGGER'S DIAGRAM

questions.text: A large 'V wave on jugular venous examination is seen in JVP-Jugular venous pulse
questions.solution:
A prominent 'V' wave observed during jugular venous (JV) examination is indicative of tricuspid regurgitation.

Explanation:
In tricuspid regurgitation, blood flows back into the right atrium during ventricular systole, leading to increased pressure and volume overload in the atrium.
This results in a pronounced 'V' wave on the JV pulse tracing, which represents the rise in right atrial pressure during ventricular contraction.

Other Clinical Features:
Additional signs of tricuspid regurgitation may include:
Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP).
Holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border, often with radiation to the right sternal border.
Symptoms of right heart failure, such as peripheral edema and ascites.

JVP waves overview: 


Other options: 

  • Tricuspid stenosis: Causes a prominent ‘a’ wave, not a V wave.

  • Atrial fibrillation: No 'a' wave, not associated with large 'v' wave.

  • Aortic regurgitation: A left heart lesion; does not affect JVP.

questions.text: Which of the following ion channels in peripheral chemoreceptors is oxygen-sensitive?
questions.solution:
Potassium channels in the peripheral chemoreceptors are oxygen-sensitive. These O2 -sensitive K+ channels are present in the type 1 glomus cells of the carotid body.
The carotid body (CB), a small neural crest-derived paired organ located at the carotid bifurcatio, is a principal component of the homeostatic acute oxygen-sensing system required to activate the brainstem respiratory centre to produce hyperventilation during hypoxaemia (e.g. in high-altitude states). The most abundant cell types in the CB glomeruli are the neuron-like glomus, or type-I, cells. In conditions leading to hypoxia inhibition of the K+ channels leads to glomus cell membrane depolarisation and increase in the firing frequency of the cells, thus resulting in Ca2+ channel opening, transmembrane Ca2+ influx and transmitter release.
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition • Page no. 505

questions.text: Which of the following ECG finding is characteristically found in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome?
questions.solution:
Wolff–Parkinson–White (WPW) syndrome is a pre‚Äëexcitation syndrome due to the presence of an accessory conduction pathway (Bundle of Kent) that bypasses the AV node.. The bundle of Kent, which is made up of these auxiliary routes, permits aberrant electrical conduction.

Classical ECG Findings of WPW Syndrome:
  1. Short PR interval (<120 ms)- normal AV nodal delay is bypassed
  2. Delta wave (slurred upstroke of QRS)- early excitation of ventricles lead to slurred upstroke
  3. Wide QRS complex (>120 ms)- early excitation leads to prolonged QRS

Reference
Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition - Page Nos. 519-522

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department after a car crash. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, neck veins distended, and heart sounds were muffled. Which of the following changes will you expect in the JVP of this patient?
questions.solution:
Cardiac tamponade is indicated by the clinical appearance of hypotension, hushed heart sounds, and dilated neck veins. The most frequent jugular venous pressure (JVP) finding in this circumstance is a missing y decline.



When fluid builds up in the pericardial area, it can cause cardiac tamponade, which impairs blood flow to the ventricles.

Beck's triad provides a classical description of this and consists of:
  • Reduced venous return is the cause of the distended neck veins.
  • cardiac sounds that are muffled (due to fluid in the pericardium)
  • Low blood pressure

Reference:
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page No. 1844, 1668-1669

questions.text: A patient developed hypotension, bradycardia and apnea on injection of an irritant substance. Which of the following physiological reflexes is involved in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The Bezold-Jarisch Reflex is responsible for the patient's circulatory collapse and apnea that were revealed following an irritating injection. Chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region—which includes the juxtacapillary region of the alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery—are activated in response to this reflex. Deep bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief episode of apnea are the outcomes, which are then followed by shallow, fast breathing.

Triggers for the Bezold-Jarisch Reflex include:
  1. Items like veratridine, phenylbiguanide, serotonin, and capsaicin
  2. myocardial ischemia and reperfusion brought on by an increase in oxygen radical generation
  3. Heart angiography uses radiocontrast agents.


Other options:

  • Bainbridge reflex: Increase in venous return → atrial stretch → reflex tachycardia, not bradycardia.

  • Cushing reflex: Due to raised intracranial pressure → causes hypertension + bradycardia + irregular respiration, not hypotension.

 

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition - Page 223.


Subject -physiology
Sub-section: cardiovascular system

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase is the action potential most dependent on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
Phase 0 sodium permeability has the greatest influence on the action potential.

Heart's action potential:

* Depolarization: Na+ inflow into the myocyte during Phase 0.

* Phase 1: K+ outflow from the myocyte during early repolarization.

* Phase 2: Plateau: Voltage-regulated L-type Ca2+ channels allow Ca2+ to enter cardiac cells.

* Phase 3: K+ Efflux during Repolarization.

* Phase 4: RMP Restoration: Na-K ATPase restores K+ and Na+.

Phases of Ventricular Action Potential
Phase Name Main Ion Movement Key Channels Involved
0 Rapid depolarization Na‚Å∫ influx Fast voltage-gated Na‚Å∫ channels
1 Initial repolarization Brief K‚Å∫ efflux, inactivation of Na‚Å∫ Transient outward K‚Å∫ channels
2 Plateau Ca²‚Å∫ influx balanced by K‚Å∫ efflux L-type Ca²‚Å∫ channels, delayed rectifier K‚Å∫
3 Repolarization K‚Å∫ efflux Delayed rectifier K‚Å∫ channels
4 Resting membrane potential Stable K‚Å∫ permeability Inward rectifier K‚Å∫ channels



Reference: Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no 511

questions.text: How are slow waves produced?
questions.solution:
Slow waves are generated by complex interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal.
insterstitial Cells of Cajal is known as the pacemaker cells of intestines.

These interstitial cells connect to smooth muscle cells in a manner akin to synapses and are situated between the layers of smooth muscle. The unique ion channels in the Cajal interstitial cells periodically open and cause inward (pacemaker) currents, which may result in slow wave activity.

These variations in membrane potential cause the interstitial cells to cycle.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 486

The interstitial cells of Cajal present in the Aurbachs plexus produces slow waves, also known as Basal Electric Rhythm(BER) which is cyclical variations in Resting Membrane Potential varying between -40 to -60 mv. When a stimulus comes in the form of food, hormones etc BER + stimulus forms the Spike potential causing Ca ions to bind to calmodulin and causing muscle contraction + movement. 

Value of BER varies with site in the GIT.
Stomach 4/min
Duodenum 12/min
Ileum 9/min
Caecum  2/min
Colon and Rectum 4-6/min

questions.text: Which of the following is the most significant but nonspecific regulator of iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Hepcidin is a key regulator of iron homeostasis that controls iron absorption in the intestine and iron release from macrophages and hepatocytes. It acts by binding to and causing the degradation of ferroportin, the cellular iron exporter, thereby reducing iron absorption from the gut and iron release from stores. Hepcidin levels increase in response to elevated iron levels, inflammation, and other factors, helping to prevent iron overload.

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 646

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase calcium absorption from the gut?
questions.solution:
Calcium ions absorption from the gut is reduced in alkaline medium. Ca2+ in alkaline media produces insoluble tricalcium phosphate, which interferes with its absorption. Alkaline pH is a better response in this situation even if phytates also reduce calcium absorption. Phytates also reduce calcium absorption but alkaline PH is a better answer.

Clinical Edge- Therefore, long-term taking Proton Pump Inhibitors can lead to osteoporosis due to decreased Ca++ absorption.
