questions.text: In the gut, migratory motor complexes recur at intervals of:
questions.solution:
MMC (migrating motor complexes) is a pattern of electrical activity in the GI tract during a regular cycle of fasting. 
They tend to occur every 90 minutes. 
These motor complexes trigger peristalsis, which facilitates the transport of indigestible substances(bone/hair etc) from the stomach through the intestine past the sphincter (ileocolic) and into the colon. 

MMC is also known as Hunger Pangs, Broomstick or Housekeeper of GIT as they clear contents and prepares gut for next meal.
They are activated by Motilin produced by Mo Cells of stomach and duodenum.


To keep it simple regarding GIT movements-

Food - Peristalsis 
Faeces - Mass Movement 
While fasting- MMC
Vomiting - Reverse Peristalsis 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 486

questions.text: What is the most important hormone that increases gallbladder contraction after a fatty meal?
questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin (CCK) is an endocrine hormone released by I cells in the upper small intestine. Its action includes stimulating pancreatic enzyme secretion, contracting the gallbladder and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi allowing bile and pancreatic juice into the intestinal lumen, augmenting the action of secretin, inhibiting gastric emptying, having a trophic effect on the pancreas and increasing enterokinase synthesis. It also augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter, preventing reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach. This hormone is the strongest stimulus for gallbladder emptying, which occurs during the intestinal phase of digestion.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 458

questions.text: Maximum water absorption in the digestive system happens in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Jejunum The GIT absorbs approximately 8L of fluid in a day out of which 2L is water. Maximum absorption occurs in the proximal small intestine because of the following reasons. Surface area: it has a large surface area for absorption due to its extensive folding, villi, and microvilli Length of transit: SI has a relatively long transit time, allowing sufficient contact time between the luminal contents and the absorptive surface Active transport of solutes: The active transport of solutes, such as sodium, across the intestinal epithelium creates an osmotic gradient. This gradient promotes the movement of water from the intestinal lumen into the epithelial cells Aquaporins: It is equipped with specialized water channels called aquaporins, which facilitate the rapid movement of water across the epithelial cells. While the small intestine is the primary site of water absorption, some water absorption also occurs in the large intestine (colon).

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 461

questions.text: Name the reflex in which there is inhibition of gastric emptying when there is acid and hypertonic solution in the duodenum.
questions.solution:
Enterogastric reflex is a reflex pathway triggered by certain stimuli in the small intestine and activates nerve cells in the myenteric plexus, causing inhibitory nerve impulses to the stomach. These impulses cause the stomach to slow or even stop the emptying of food into the small intestine. The purpose of enterogastric reflex is to allow the body more time to digest an incoming meal and to ensure necessary nutrients are absorbed. This can prevent the symptoms of a substandard nutrient intake, such as malnutrition or malabsorption.



Reference- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 811,812

questions.text: Choose what van den Bergh test is for
questions.solution:
The van den Bergh test is a laboratory procedure used to measure bilirubin levels in the blood. More specifically it determines the amount of direct/conjugated bilirubin. The direct component of bilirubin is not affected by the test, while the indirect component is. The test uses specific reagents, typically sodium nitrite and diazotized sulfanilic acid, to react with bilirubin and give a red colour with the formation of a diazo compound. The colour intensity on a colour scale from 0 to 5 is compared with standards to get relative proportions of direct and indirect bilirubin. This test can be used to measure the proportion of each component of bilirubin in newborns with jaundice and monitor the efficacy of phototherapy.

 

Reference-:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 316

questions.text: The greatest absorption of short-chain fatty acids generated by bacteria occurs in the:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Colon 
 
  • Humans lack the enzymes to degrade the bulk of dietary fibres.
  • Thus these nondigestible carbohydrates pass the upper gastrointestinal tract unaffected and are fermented in the cecum and the large intestine by the anaerobic caecal and colonic microbiota.
  •  Fermentation results in production of multiple groups of metabolites of which short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are the major  metabolic by products.
  • Examples of short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) includes-
    • ACETATE
    • PROPIONATE
    • BUTYRATE            
  • SCFA constitute the major anions in the hindgut contents which are effectively absorbed in the large intestine. Thus option 4 – COLON is the answer to this question.
  Maximum absorption of metabolites-  Jejunum > ileum > colon > duodenum except : 
1. Vit B12 & Bile salt - Terminal Ileum
2. SCFA - colon
3. Iron and folate - duodenum

questions.text: Which of the following conditions falls under the category of gastrointestinal neurocrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: GRP

Neurocrine gut hormones are the ones secreted from the neurons located in the gastrointestinal tract.
The examples of neurocrine gut hormones include the following :-
  • GASTRIN RELEASING PEPTIDE
  • GHRELIN
  • ENKEPHALINS
  • GIP (glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide), Peptide YY, and Somatostatin are gastrointestinal hormones that are released by endocrine cells in the gastrointestinal tract. They do not fall under the category of gastrointestinal neurocrine. GIP stimulates insulin release in response to food intake, Peptide YY regulates appetite and inhibits gastric emptying, and Somatostatin inhibits the release of other gastrointestinal hormones.

questions.text: What is the the primary action of Nitric oxide (NO) in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:

  • Inhibition of platelet aggregation

May cause pain in the pit of stomach

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hunger pangs is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Typically begin 6 to 8 hours after last meal
 
  • Hunger Pangs are referred to  a series of high amplitude contractions of the stomach and small intestine  which forms  a cycle of quiescence and contractions known as the Migrating Motor Complex( MMC).
  • It plays a “housekeeping” role prior to the next meal and  contributes to the development of hunger.
  • MMC mainly originates in the stomach & can travel to the distal end of ileum which are triggered by the release of a hormone called ghrelin
  • As food moves from the stomach to the colon, the MMC washes and sweeps away the undigested food particles, cleans and prepares the gastrointestinal tract for the next meal.
  • The entire cycle of MMC occurs every 90 mins
  • It comprises 4 stages:-
    1. Prolonged period of quiescence
    2. Increased frequency of action potentials and smooth muscle contractions
    3. A few minutes of peak electrical & mechanical activity
    4. Declining activity
  • Hunger pangs typically begin 12 to 24 hours after the last meal, not 6 to 8 hours.  .
  • Hunger pangs can cause discomfort and pain in the pit of the stomach, and they can become more intense over time if food is not consumed.
  • In cases of starvation, hunger pangs may reach their greatest intensity in the first few days and then subside as the body adjusts to the lack of food. 
     


Reference:Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology 25th Edition Page no 486, 487

questions.text: Which of the following factors raises serum Hepcidin levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Inflammation
 
  • hepcidin is an example of Acute Phase Reactant, increases during inflammation 
    Hepcidin is a hormone that regulates how our body uses iron. 
  • Hepcidin inhibits the cellular efflux of iron by binding to it , and inducing the degradation of  Ferroportin , the sole iron exporter in iron-transporting cells. In turn, hepcidin synthesis is increased by iron loading and decreased by anaemia and hypoxia
  • Hepcidin is elevated in the following inflammatory conditions like :-
    • Rheumatic diseases  
    • Inflammatory bowel disease 
    • Chronic infections
    • Multiple myeloma   
Hypoxia leads to increase erythropoitin and that causes decrease in Hepcidin as more amount of Hemoglobin needs to be synthesized.

questions.text: Amylin: is secreted by which of the following types of islet cells?
questions.solution:
Amylin is a peptide hormone that is co-secreted with insulin by the beta cells of the pancreas. It is also known as islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) and is involved in the regulation of glucose homeostasis.
Amylin helps to slow the rate at which food empties from the stomach and reduces the amount of glucagon secretion, which in turn helps to lower blood glucose levels.
Therefore, the correct option is 2. Beta cells.

Amylin as  it slows down Glucose absorption, prevents postprandial hyperglycaemia. Hence an amylin analogue PRAMLINTIDE is used in the treatment of Diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following are incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone secreted by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon. It acts via G-protein-coupled receptors on enteric neurons in the duodenum and colon, promoting smooth muscle contraction in the stomach and intestines between meals. M cells, on the other hand, are microfold cells found in the mucosa-associated lymphoid tissues of the small intestine, such as Peyer‘s patches, and are involved in transporting luminal antigens to lymphoid follicles to trigger an immune response.

Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum, duodenum, and jejunum, and it stimulates gastric acid secretion and mucosal growth.


Secretin is secreted by S cells in the duodenum and primarily functions to stimulate the secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the pancreas and duodenum.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 459 .

questions.text: Which of the following is an orexigenic hormone?
questions.solution:
Ghrelin is an orexigenic hormone that plays a crucial role in stimulating appetite.

It is produced by the oxyntic gland area of the stomach and is mainly involved in the central regulation of food intake. Ghrelin is also secreted by the pancreas and adrenal glands.

Functions of Ghrelin:
Increases appetite and food intake (orexigenic effect).

Stimulates growth hormone secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary.

Enhances gastric acid secretion and gastrointestinal motility, preparing the body for food intake.

Regulates the distribution and rate of energy use.

Inhibits the release of leptin and promotes lipolysis.

Ghrelin levels rise during fasting, peaking just before food intake or when an individual expects a meal. After feeding begins, ghrelin levels typically decrease within 1 hour.

Other options:

  • Leptin: Secreted by adipose tissue → decreases appetite (satiety signal).

  • Cholecystokinin (CCK): Secreted by duodenum → promotes satiety, slows gastric emptying.

  • Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (α-MSH): Acts on hypothalamus to decrease appetite.



In contrast, hormones such as melanocyte-stimulating hormone, cholecystokinin, and leptin are anorexigenic and function to decrease appetite.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones does not directly act on the the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Gastrin does not have a direct effect on the pancreas; rather, it primarily stimulates gastric acid secretion and promotes the growth of gastric mucosa.

Cholecystokinin (CCK) has the following effects:

Stimulates:

Secretion of pancreatic enzymes
Bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas
Contraction of the gallbladder
Growth of the exocrine pancreas
Inhibits:
Gastric emptying
Secretin enhances the secretion of bicarbonate (HCO??) by the ductal cells of both the pancreas and the duodenum. It is secreted by the S cells located in the upper small intestine.

The functions of secretin include:

Primary function:
Stimulating bicarbonate secretion by the ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum.
Other functions:
Enhancing the effects of CCK
Inhibiting gastrin release
Reducing gastric acid secretion
Causing contraction of the pyloric sphincter
Exerting a trophic effect on the pancreas
Insulin secretion is typically stimulated by glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1).

Both GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) are classified as incretins and serve as potent stimulators of insulin secretion while also inhibiting glucagon secretion. These peptides are released in the gastrointestinal tract following a meal, leading to an anticipatory increase in blood insulin levels in preparation for the absorption of glucose and amino acids from the meal.

questions.text: Which among the following functions is not carried out by the intestinal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Bile salt secretion is not done by intestinal epithelium. Bile salts are secreted by hepatocytes in the liver and stored in the gallbladder, then released into the duodenum through the bile duct.

The intestinal epithelium performs several important functions:
  1. Mucous secretion- done by goblet cells in the intestinal lining.
  2. Secretion of digestive enzymes- enterocytes at the brush border secrete enzymes like disaccharidases (lactase, maltase) and peptidases.
  3. Absorption of ions, water, and nutrients- intestinal epithelial cells actively absorb Na‚Å∫, Cl‚Åª, water, glucose, amino acids, etc.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 819

questions.text: Which of the following has GLUT-2 glucose transporter?
questions.solution:
The main location of the GLUT 2 glucose transporter is the liver.

The liver is the only organ where GLUT 2 is present on the apical portion of the cell, absent from the kidney and small intestine.


 

Other options:

  • Small intestine: Uses GLUT-5 (fructose absorption) and SGLT-1 (glucose/galactose absorption) at apical side; GLUT-2 is only at basolateral side for transfer, not primary absorption.

  • Kidney: Uses SGLT-2 (apical) and GLUT-2 (basolateral in proximal tubule), but the classical exam answer is liver.

  • Brain: Uses GLUT-1 (BBB) and GLUT-3 (neurons), not GLUT-2.



Reference
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition - Page no: 974-976, 979-980, 983

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is absorbed in the terminal ileum, with the help of intrinsic factor produced by the stomach.

In a patient who has undergone complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the most likely outcome is:

  • Malabsorption of Vitamin B12, leading to:

    • Clinical Features:
      Hematologic:

    • Megaloblastic anemia (large RBCs)

    • Pancytopenia (in severe cases)

      Neurologic: (unique to B12, not seen with folate deficiency)

    • Peripheral neuropathy (tingling, numbness)

      Other:

    • Glossitis ("beefy tongue")

    • Weight loss, diarrhea (if underlying malabsorption)
       

    • Posterior column involvement: ↓ proprioception, vibration

    • Subacute Combined Degeneration: dorsal + lateral column demyelination → ataxia, spasticity

    • Cognitive decline, depression


      Laboratory Findings:

  • ↑ MCV (macrocytic anemia)

  • Hypersegmented neutrophils

  • ↓ Serum B12

  • ↑ Homocysteine (also seen in folate deficiency)

  • ↑ Methylmalonic acid (specific for B12 deficiency)

  • Anti-intrinsic factor or anti-parietal cell antibodies (in pernicious anemia)


    Other options:

  • Folic acid: Absorbed in the proximal jejunum — though partial jejunal resection may reduce absorption, B12 deficiency is more prominent and clinically significant after ileal resection.

  • Gastric ulcer: Not directly related to ileal/jejunal resection.

  • Constipation: Unlikely; if anything, such resections often cause diarrhea or steatorrhea due to bile salt malabsorption.


Reference:Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no 470,478

questions.text: The graph that follows shows the maximum renal tubular transit for glucose excretion in a diabetic patient. In a patient with a blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL and a glomerular filtration rate of 90 mL/min, what will the urine glucose level be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  30 mg/min
 

We have to find the total amount of glucose excreated (urine glucose)

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose – Total reabsorbed glucose

  • Total filtered glucose = GFR x plasma concentration

  • Total reabsorbed glucose = transport maximum

Urine glucose = (90 ml/min x 2mg/ml) – 150 mg/min

=180 mg/min – 150 mg/min

=30 mg/min

questions.text: Assuming that no proteins were filtered, calculate net filtration with the following data: PGC = 42 mm Hg (Hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries) PiGC= 16 mm Hg (Oncotic pressure of the plasma in glomerular capillaries) PBC = 12 mm Hg (Hydrostatic pressure In Bowman's space) Assume that no proteins were filtered:
questions.solution:
The net filtration pressure is 14mm of Hg.
There are four pressures to consider: two hydrostatic pressures and two oncotic pressure. These are the Starling forces.
Hence, Net Filtration Pressure(NFP)=PGC-(piGC+ PBS)=42-(12+16)=14mmHg.

PGC-Hydrostatic pressure of the glomerulus.
PBS-Hydrostatic pressure In Bowman's space
piGC-Oncotic pressure of the plasma.

questions.text: All of the aforementioned factors increase GFR, except which one:
questions.solution:
In some disorders related to a blockage of the urinary tract, Bowman's capsule pressure may have an extremely increased level, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This may be caused by the collection of substances like calcium oxide or uric acid, which form stones that block the flow of urine in the ureter, elevating the pressure inside Bowman's capsule, thereby reducing GFR and could eventually create hydronephrosis (swelling and enlargement of the kidney's pelvis and calyces). Unless the obstruction is freed, this could result in damage to, or even destruction of, the kidney.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

questions.text: Select the correct diluting segment of kidney.
questions.solution:
The Loop of Henle allows for water to be removed from the filtrate in the nephron by passing it through a hypertonic interstitium. The descending limb is permeable to water through aquaporin-I, while Na, K and Cl are cotransported out in the thick segment of the ascending limb, thus leading to fluid in the descending limb becoming hypertonic and ascending limb hypotonic. This results in approximately 20% of filtered water entering the distal tubule, with a TF/P of inulin of 5. The ascending limb vidly reabsorbs most of the ions, including sodium, potassium, and chloride, but is virtually impermeable to water and urea. For this reason, it is referred to as the diluting segment because it also dilutes the tubular fluid.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 674

choices.text: Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.text: Except for the following components, all are responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb

The countercurrent flow of tubular fluid in the loop of Henle and the blood in the vasa recta creates a countercurrent exchange system. This system allows for the reabsorption of water and solutes from the tubular fluid while maintaining the concentration gradient in the renal medulla.
  • Thin Descending Limb: The thin descending limb is highly permeable to water but not to solutes
  • Thin Ascending Limb: At the bottom of the loop of Henle, the thin descending limb transitions into the thin ascending limb. The thin ascending limb is also permeable to water but does not actively transport solutes
  • Thick Ascending Limb: As the thin ascending limb continues to ascend towards the renal cortex, it transitions into the thick ascending limb. The thick ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively transports solutes such as sodium, chloride, and potassium out of the tubule into the interstitial fluid



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 675,676,677

questions.text: Proteoglycan present in Glomerular basement membrane is:
questions.solution:
The glomerular capillary membrane makes the filtration barrier that allows for the passage of certain substances from the blood into the glomerular filtrate. This membrane consists of three major layers: capillary endothelium, capillary basement membrane, and layer of epithelial cells surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane (podocytes). The capillary endothelium layer is freely permeable to everything in the blood except for red blood cells and platelets, up to a size of 4 nm in diameter. The capillary basement membrane contains proteins, such as laminin, type VI collagen, nidogen, and heparan sulfate proteoglycan (HSPG). These proteins form a meshwork which effectively prevents filtration of plasma proteins. The layer of podocytes surround the capillary basement membrane and have long foot-like processes with gaps in-between called slit pores, which are 25 nm wide. It is through these slit pores that the glomerular filtrate moves. The total area of glomerular capillary endothelium across which filtration occurs in humans is approximately 0.8m. This membrane is selective in how it permits materials through, allowing related to their size, charge, and other properties.



Reference :Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition Page no 1474

questions.text: The Proteoglycan is located in the glomerular basement membrane. Select from the options the most appropriate one for the statement mentioned.
What results in the Impaired function of aquaporin?
questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus is a disorder that results from impaired function of aquaporins, which are proteins that form channels in cell membranes and allow water to move in and out of cells. In diabetes insipidus, aquaporins are either missing or are malfunctioning, thus preventing the regulation of the amount of water that can enter cells. As a consequence, too much water enters cells which results in excessive urination and thirst. This is because the kidneys’ ability to reabsorb water is impaired, resulting in reduced concentration of solutes in the body and consequently, an excessive amount of water need to be urinated out of the body in order to keep the solute concentration balanced. Therefore, impaired function of aquaporins can lead to the development of diabetes insipidus due to their essential role in the regulation of water movement in and out of cells.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 675

questions.text: U x X/P provides clearance. What does "U" stand for?

questions.text: An increase in central venous pressure causes the following effects:
questions.solution:
When the atria are stretched and the ECF volume is increased by the infusion of isotonic saline, ANP production is enhanced. The rate of ANP secretion is proportional to how much the atria are stretched by increases in central venous pressure. Stretching the ventricles causes an increase in BNP secretion. BNP secretion increases in direct proportion to how much stretched the ventricles are.
The increased ANP will then cause natriuresis

questions.text: Renal Autoregulation does not occur because of:
questions.solution:
THE MYOGENIC AUTOREGULATION OF GFR AND RENAL BLOOD FLOW The ability of individual blood vessels to resist stretching under elevated arterial pressure helps to maintain a reasonably steady renal blood flow and GFR. Stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction helps prevent excessive increases in renal blood flow and GFR by increasing vascular resistance when arterial pressure increases.

If there is decrease in GFR-> activation of RAAS pathway-> Angiotensin 2 helps in Na+ and water reabsorption increasing blood volume and mesangial cells contraction-> Increase in GFR 

Tubuloglomerular feedback also helps in maintaining auto-regulation of GFR

Therefore, option 2- Presympathetic nerves is the correct option. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 582

questions.text: Which of these best describes the mechanism of 'vasopressin escape' in SIADH
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape occurs due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 receptors. In SIADH, prolonged exposure to anti-diuretic hormone results in downregulation of aquaporin 2 receptors. This maintains euvolemic status of the body and doesn't lead to dilutional hyponatremia by preventing excessive reabsorption of water despite high levels of ADH. This phenomenon is known as vasopressin escape.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was taken to the emergency room with confusion and lethargy. His body temperature is 36.7°C, blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg, heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and respirations are 10 beats per minute. pCO2 is 49 mmHg, pH is 7.59, and pO2 is 85 mmHg. Which of the following conditions best describes his acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Metabolic alkalosis

Method to calculate the acid base status is as follows
  1. We need 3 values to find out the answer. They are pH, pCO2 and HCO3
  2. The pCO2 value correlates with respiratory status
HCO3 value correlates with metabolic status
  1. Normal values are pH = 7.4     PCO2 = 40      HCO3 = 24

 
  1. Step 1 : pH <7.4 = acidosis
              pH >7.4 = alkalosis
  1. Step 2 : we have to find out if it is respiratory or metabolic
              If pCO2 indicates acidosis and pH indicates acidosis – Respiratory acidosis
              If pCO2 indicates alkalosis and pH indicates alkalosis – Respiratory alkalosis
              If HCO3 indicates acidosis and pH indicates acidosis – Metabolic acidosis
              If HCO3 indicates alkalosis and pH indicates alkalosis – Metabolic alkalosis

Another method is to remember ROME “RESPIRATORY OPPOSITE METABOLIC EQUAL



In this question pH is 7.59 which means alkalosis. pCO2 is 49 mmHg which indicates acidosis. Since the respiratory quotient is not correlating with alkalosis it seems to be a compensatory mechanism to overcome metabolic alkalosis.


In this question pH is 7.59 which means alkalosis. pCO2 is 49 mmHg which indicates acidosis. Since the respiratory quotient is not correlating with alkalosis it seems to be a compensatory mechanism to overcome metabolic alkalosis.

If we use the ROMS( Respiratory opposite Metabolic Same) mnemonic pH and pCO2 are both increasing which indicates metabolic alkalosis.



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 705,635

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man needed dialysis, so he went to the hospital. An arterial blood sample was collected for testing prior to sending him for dialysis.
Which of the laboratory results listed below indicates compensated metabolic acidosis?
1. Low PCO2, normal bicarbonate and, high pH
2. Low PCO2, low bicarbonate, low pH
3. High PCO2, high bicarbonate and, low pH
4. High PCO2, low bicarbonate and High PH
questions.solution:
With or without a compensatory drop in bicarbonate (HCO3), respiratory alkalosis is characterised by a primary fall in carbon dioxide partial pressure (Pco2); pH may be high or close to normal. An increase in respiratory volume or rate (hyperventilation), or both, is the cause. Acute or chronic respiratory alkalosis is possible.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same

questions.text:
A young woman is discovered unconscious after taking an undetermined amount of sleeping pills at an undetermined hour.
The following results are obtained from an arterial blood sample: pH 7.10, HCO2 32 meq/liter, and pCO2 68 mmHg.
Which of the following statements best sums up this patient's acid-base condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation

Step 1 : pH is 7.10 which indicates acidosis
Step 2 : pCO2 is 68 mmHg I.e higher than normal  which means respiratory acidosis
Step 3 : HCO3 is raised suggesting metabolic compensation
Therefore the answer will be Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation.

In case of metabolic acidosis, Winters Formula is used to calculate the required pCO2 compensation
Winters formula predicted PaCO2 = 1.5 x [HCO3-] + 8

choices.text: The oncotic pressure of the fluid leaving the capillaries is less than that of fluid entering it

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding glomerular capillaries is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: The oncotic pressure of the fluid leaving the capillaries is less than that of fluid entering it

Option 1 : the oncotic pressure of fluid leaving the capillaries is more than that of fluid entering as last amino acids and proteins are not filtered through that glomerular membrane but plasma is freely filtered. Thus the oncotic pressure increases
Option 2 : the glucose concentration in the capillaries is same as that in the glomerular filtrate as glucose is freely filtered through the membrane via the fenestrated endothelium and the negatively charged membrane.
Option 3 : Constriction of Afferent arteriole will lead to reduced blood flow in the glomerular capillaries leading to decreased GFR. Constriction of efferent arteriole on the other hand leads to increased contact time of blood with the bowman’s capsule and thus increased GFR
Option 4 : hematocrit is the ratio of volume of RBCs to the volume of blood. the hematocrit of the fluid leaving the glomerular capillaries is generally the same as or slightly higher than that of the fluid entering it. This occurs because the glomerular capillaries primarily filter small molecules, ions, and water, while larger molecules such as red blood cells are not usually filtered. Consequently, the concentration of red blood cells and the hematocrit remain relatively constant throughout the process of filtration in the glomerulus.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 665-669

All the other 3 markers are used routinely to determine the renal function.

questions.text: Which section of the renal tubule reabsorbs the most water when there are high levels of ADH present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Proximal tubule
 
  • Vasopressin or Anti Diuretic Hormone is secreted by Hypothalamus and is stored in Posterior Pituitary.
  • It is released from Posterior Pituitary in response to increase in plasma osmolarity and decrease in blood volume.
  • It acts on V2 receptors present in the Principal cells of the Collecting Ducts which leads to increased insertion of Aquaporin receptors. This leads to water reabsorption
  • However though ADH mainly acts on the Collecting Ducts still maximum reabsorption occurs in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule
  • Option 1, Proximal Tubule, is correct. When there are high levels of ADH (Antidiuretic hormone) present, the permeability of the walls of the collecting ducts and distal convoluted tubules to water increases.
  • However, the majority of water reabsorption occurs in the proximal tubule, which is the first segment of the renal tubule.
  • The proximal tubule is responsible for reabsorbing approximately 65% of the filtered water, along with ions, glucose, amino acids, and other solutes.
  • This occurs through both active and passive transport mechanisms, including the use of transport proteins and ion channels.
  • Therefore, in the presence of high levels of ADH, the proximal tubule would still be responsible for reabsorbing the majority of the filtered water, even though the collecting ducts and distal convoluted tubules have become more permeable to water.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 673

questions.text: Where in the tubule would a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: D
 
  • Vasopressin or Anti Diuretic Hormone is secreted by Hypothalamus and is stored in Posterior Pituitary.
  • It is released from Posterior Pituitary in response to increase in plasma osmolarity and decrease in blood volume.
  • It acts on V2 receptors present in the Principal cells of the Collecting Ducts which leads to increased insertion of Aquaporin receptors. This leads to water reabsorption

In Central diabetes Insipidus there is deficiency of Anti Diuretic Hormone. This decreases the water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, thereby decreasing the tubular fluid osmolarity in the collecting ducts.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 673,65,327

questions.text: Regardless of the GFR value, a fixed portion of the filtered load is absorbed in the proximal tubule. What causes this?
questions.solution:
The correct option for the given question is 1. Tubuloglomerular feedback.
  • Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) is a mechanism that regulates the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by controlling the diameter of the afferent arteriole. The TGF mechanism involves the detection of changes in sodium chloride concentration in the macula densa cells of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) located in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • When the GFR increases, the flow of filtrate through the tubules also increases, and the concentration of sodium chloride in the macula densa cells increases. This triggers the release of vasoconstrictor chemicals, such as adenosine and thromboxane, which constrict the afferent arteriole, reducing the GFR.
  • Conversely, when the GFR decreases, the concentration of sodium chloride in the macula densa cells decreases, and this triggers the release of vasodilator chemicals, such as nitric oxide, which dilate the afferent arteriole, increasing the GFR.
  • However, regardless of the GFR value, a fixed portion of the filtered load is absorbed in the proximal tubule. This is due to the fact that the proximal tubule has a high capacity for reabsorption and can reabsorb up to 65% of the filtered load. 
     

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 672

choices.text: Basement membrane carries a net negative charge
Myoglobin is filtered more readily than albumin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about glomerular filtration is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Negatively charged molecules are filtered readily
 
  • Glomerular Filtration Barrier is composed
    • Fenestrated Capillary Endothelium
    • Basement Membrane – Composed of Type IV collagen, Heparan sulphate
    • Visceral Epithelial Layer consisting of Podocyte foot process
  • Basement membrane composed of Heparan Sulphate which is negatively charged and hence prevents the entry of negatively charged molecules like albumin
  • Fenestrated Capillary Endothelium prevents entry of molecules more than 100 nm in size ; slit diaphragm prevents entry of particles size more than 50 nm. Therefore Low molecular weight molecules filter easily.
  • Molecular weight of Myoglobin ( 16 kilo DA)  is much less compared to molecular weight of albumin (64kDA). Therefore Myoglobin is filtered much easily compared to Albumin.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667,668

However though ADH mainly acts on the Collecting Ducts still maximum reabsorption occurs in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding given cystometrogram?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a cystometrogram which is a graphical plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of urine in bladder.

I- It is the initial slight rise in pressure when the urinary bladder begins to receive urine post void and not due to residual volume.

II- It is a long and flat segment. The Laplace's law is obeyed in this segment. As tension increases due to progressive filling of bladder with urine, there is only slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full. 

III- A sharp and sudden rise due to trigger of micturition reflex and not its failure.

questions.text:
With reference to the adjacent diagram, which of the following is correct?

1. A- Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin, D- PAHA
2. A- Bicarbonate, B- Glucose, C- Inulin, D- PAHA
3. A- Inulin, B- Bicarbonate, C- Glucose, D- PAHA
4. A- Glucose, B- Inulin, C- PAHA, D- Bicarbonate
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin, D- PAHA

The given graph of the percent filtered load remaining along the distance of the nephron represents the relative amounts of various substances which are filtered through the glomerulus into the tubules.

  • Substance A is being completely reabsorbed within the proximal convoluted tubule and thus likely represents glucose or amino acids. 
  • Substance B is absorbed to a great extent in the PCT, but is still excreted in the urine in minor quantities. This is likely to represent the curve of electrolytes such as Na+, HCO3-, or even water.
  • Substance C's filtered load (i.e. amount) stays constant throughout the nephron and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted, representing Inulin, which is ideal for the estimation of the glomerular filtration rate.
  • Substance D is not only freely filtered but also secreted to the extent that it is removed completely by the body. This is likely to be para-amino hippuric acid (PAH), a substance that is used for the estimation of renal plasma flow.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page. No- 677, 681.

questions.text: All of the following Sodium transporters are present in the early part of PCT, except?
questions.solution:
Na-H Antiporter, Na- glucose co transporter, Na-K ATPase are all found in the Proximal Part of PCT.

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except
questions.solution:
• Efferent arteriolar constriction → increases glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure → increases GFR (mild constriction).

  • Decreased capillary oncotic pressure → reduces opposing force to filtration → increases GFR.

  • Increased renal blood flow → raises glomerular hydrostatic pressure → increases GFR.

  • Ureteric stone → causes back pressure in Bowman's space due to obstruction of urine outflow → decreases GFR.

Hence, ureteric obstruction (as from a ureteric stone) reduces GFR.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with hypertension presents at the hospital. His blood pressure upon examination is 150/90, and is afebrile. Further evaluation reveals normal serum renin levels, leading to a diagnosing of conn's syndrome. All of the following conditions would be seen in conn's syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Conn’s syndrome (Primary hyperaldosteronism) is caused by excess aldosterone secretion from the adrenal cortex.

Effects of aldosterone:

  1. Sodium retention → hypertension

  2. Potassium excretion → hypokalemia

  3. Hydrogen ion excretion → metabolic alkalosis

  4. Increased distal tubular flow → polyuria and polydipsia

Therefore:

  • Metabolic alkalosis → seen due to H‚Å∫ loss

  • Hypokalemia → seen due to K‚Å∫ loss

  • Polyuria → secondary to hypokalemia-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

Metabolic acidosis is not seen in Conn’s syndrome; it occurs in conditions with loss of bicarbonate or impaired H‚Å∫ excretion, which is the opposite of what happens here.

Hence, the exception is metabolic acidosis.

Inhibits the Na-Cl in early distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the descending limb of loop of henle
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the ascending limb of loop of henle

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazide diuretics?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics are commonly used to treat hypertension, edema, and nephrolithiasis.

Mechanism:

  • Act on the early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron.

  • Inhibit the Na‚Å∫-Cl‚Åª symporter, reducing sodium and chloride reabsorption.

  • This leads to increased excretion of Na‚Å∫, Cl‚Åª, and water, along with mild potassium loss.

  • Additional effects:

    • Increase calcium reabsorption → useful in preventing calcium kidney stones.

Other options for comparison:

  • Late DCT: Targeted by potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., thiazide-like spironolactone acts elsewhere)

  • Descending loop of Henle: Impermeable to Na‚Å∫, site of water reabsorption

  • Ascending loop of Henle: Target of loop diuretics (inhibit Na‚Å∫-K‚Å∫-2Cl‚Åª pump)

questions.text: Which of the following decreases GFR
questions.solution:
• GFR is determined by sum of the hydrostatic and colloid osmotic forces across the glomerular membrane.
  • It is also dependant on Glomerular Kf (glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient). Formula: GFR= Kf[(glomerular hydrostatic pressure- glomerular oncotic pressure)-(bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure- Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure)]

Hence factors that increase GFR include:
(1) increase in glomerular capillary filteration coefficient
(2) increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure
(3)decrease in bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure
(4) decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure .

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 666-667.

questions.text: Erythropoietin is produced by all of the following organs except
questions.solution:
• Erythropoietin is secreted by interstitial cells in the peri-tubular capillary bed of the kidneys and by perivenous hepatocytes in the liver.
  • It is also generated in the brain, where it provides a safeguarding effect against excitotoxic harm caused by hypoxia; and in the uterus and oviducts, where it is stimulated by estrogen and seems to facilitate estrogen-driven angiogenesis.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 696.

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding creatinine clearance?
questions.solution:
• The correct statement is that creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance.

• Creatinine is partially secreted and never reabsorbed. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine (CCr) is often used to estimate GFR, but because creatinine is also secreted by the renal tubules, its clearance slightly overestimates the actual GFR compared to inulin.

• Inulin is completely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, making it a reliable marker for accurate GFR estimation.

• PAH (para-aminohippuric acid) at low plasma concentrations is fully filtered and secreted. Hence, it is used to estimate renal plasma flow.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about GFR? GFR-Glomerular filtration rate RPF- Renal Plasma Flow
questions.solution:
The accurate statement regarding the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is that an increase in renal plasma flow (RPF) leads to an increase in GFR.

With glomerular hydrostatic pressure remaining constant, an increase in blood flow to the glomerulus generally results in a higher GFR, whereas a decrease in blood flow tends to lower the GFR.

Additionally, sympathetic stimulation can cause a reduction in GFR due to constriction of the afferent arterioles. Strong activation of the renal sympathetic nerves can constrict the renal arterioles, resulting in decreased renal blood flow and subsequently a reduced GFR.
 

Other options:

  • Afferent arteriolar constriction: ↓ blood flow into glomerulus → ↓ GFR (not increase).

  • Sympathetic activation: Causes vasoconstriction (especially afferent arteriole) → ↓ RPF and ↓ GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following kidney segments is associated with maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) has a high capacity for reabsorption, hence it has specialised features to aid with this. It is lined with simple cuboidal epithelial cells which have a brush border to increase surface area on the apical side. The epithelial cells have large amounts of mitochondria present to support the processes involved in transporting ions and substances.
The proximal tubule can be divided into pars convolute and pars recta. The pars convolute resides in the renal cortex and it can further be divided into 2 segments; S1 (segment 1) and the proximal part of S2. The pars recta is a straight segment present in the outer medulla. It makes up the distal part of S2 and S3. A large amount of reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule. The proximal tubules reabsorb about 65% of water, sodium, potassium and chloride, 100% of glucose, 100% amino acids, and 85-90% of bicarbonate. The driving force for water reabsorption is a trans tubular osmotic gradient established by the reabsorption of solutes. Ref -Medical Physiology, 2e Updated Edition • Page no 789

questions.text: Which of the following will decrease the GFR?
questions.solution:
GFR = Kf[(glomerular hydrostatic pressure - glomerular oncotic pressure) - (Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure - Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure)]
Hence increase in Bowman's hydrostatic pressure will decrease GFR.
Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:
• Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf.
•Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure.
• Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure.
• Filtration fraction: An increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.
Ref- Ganong review of Medical Physiology 26th edition Page 677-678

choices.text: It is due to the plasticity the bladder has
It is due to the elasticity of bladder
The graph is flat due to the contractility of the bladder
Micturition occur at the start of Ib

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding phase Ib of a cystometrogram
questions.solution:
Phase Ib of a cystometrogram, which plots intravesical pressure against bladder volume, represents the bladder's plasticity. The bladder's capacity to flex without breaking is referred to as plasticity. There are three segments that define the cystometrogram curve:

1. A small initial increase in pressure upon introducing the first volume increments.

2. A lengthy, almost level segment (Ib) as volume rises continue.

3. A quick, intense increase in pressure that occurs when the micturition reflex is activated.

The graph's dotted line shows the pressure-volume relationship in the absence of micturition. The law of Laplace, which states that pressure (P) in a spherical organ is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius, is demonstrated by the flatness of segment Ib.

Reference
Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition - Page 681,682

questions.text: Which hormone can you identify from the picture?
questions.solution:
Release of growth hormone is stimulated by strenuous exercise. Also during sleep, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur.

Factors which stimulate secretion of growth hormone:
(1) starvation, especially with severe protein deficiency;
(2) hypoglycemia or low concentration of fatty acids in the blood;
(3) exercise;
(4) excitement;
(5) trauma; and
(6) ghrelin, a hormone secreted by the stomach before meals.

questions.text: Which hormones fall under the hypothalamus's inhibitory control?
questions.solution:
Both growth hormone and prolactin are under inhibitory control of hypothalamus.
 
  • Growth hormone release is regulated by the hypothalamus, which also secretes somatostatin, an inhibitor of growth hormone release, as well as growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH).
  • The level of growth hormone release will therefore depend on how these hypothalamic elements interact with one another to affect the pituitary.
  • Hence, the growth hormone secretion stimuli may work by boosting hypothalamic GHRH secretion, lowering somatostatin secretion, or both.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page no 908, 917

questions.text: At the start of puberty, which of the following hormones has a permissive effect?
questions.solution:
The permissive effect is a biochemical phenomenon in which the presence of one hormone allows another hormone to exert its full effects on a target cell. For example, thyroid hormones have a permissive relationship with certain reproductive hormones

Leptin has a permissive action at the onset of puberty by increasing GnRH
 
  • Leptin, a hormone that causes satiety and is released by fat cells, may link body weight to puberty: Leptin injections can restore fertility in obese  mice that are infertile due to a lack of leptin production.
  • In young female mice, leptin therapy also causes early puberty.
Clinical Edge- Infertility is seen in female athletes who have very low body fat percentage. As leptin is released from fat cells.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 319

questions.text: At the start of puberty, which of the following hormones has a permissive effect?

Leptin accelerates GnRH pulsatility in Hypothalamic neurons, fastening puberty.

questions.text: Select the type of lipase that is controlled by glucagon.
questions.solution:
Hormone sensitive lipase, the enzyme which mobilizes fatty acids from triacylglycerol stores in adipose tissue is inhibited by Postaglandin-E  and Insulin while Glucagon, ACTH, epinephrine and vasopressin promote activation of the enzyme.

This lipase is distinct from lipoprotein lipase, which catalyzes lipoprotein triacylglycerol hydrolysis before its uptake into extrahepatic tissues.

questions.text: On which of the following does sex chromatin testing depend?
questions.solution:
In females, 1-15% of polymorphonuclear leukocytes can be seen with a small "drumstick" shaped segment of chromatin known as barr body protruding from the nucleus, which indicates the presence of an inactive X chromosome. This is not visible in males. The Lyon hypothesis suggests that one of the two X chromosomes in female cells is randomly inactivated, and that all but one of the X chromosomes present in a cell with more than two X chromosomes will be inactivated. This can be observed in a variety of types of cells, most notably within the nuclei of polymorphonuclear leukocytes, with the inactive X chromosome being visible in the form of a "drumstick" of chromatin known as a Barr body.

questions.text: Why is insulin resistance is seen in liver disease?

While hepatic steatosis (fatty liver) can also play a role, it is the dysfunction of liver cells that is a key factor in the development of insulin resistance.

questions.text: Select the drug which acts through Tyrosine Kinase receptor.
questions.solution:
Tyrosine kinase receptors are integral components of the insulin signaling pathway. They are transmembrane proteins that bind and respond to insulin in the bloodstream, transducing the signal across the cell membrane and into the cell itself. Upon insulin binding to the receptor, the intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity is activated and the receptor autophosphorylates, resulting in the recruitment of adaptor proteins that further activate multiple downstream signaling pathways that regulate many cellular metabolic processes. This ultimately results in the cellular uptake of glucose, essential for maintaining an adequate glucose homeostasis. The tyrosine kinase receptor plays a pivotal role in insulin's mechanism of action, as it is essential for transducing the extracellular signal across the membrane and for regulating the intracellular metabolic processes that enable the cellular uptake of glucose.
 

1. Nuclear receptors- Sex hormones 
2. Cell membrane receptors- GPCR or Tyrosine Kinase receptors

  • GPCR - remaining vast majority of hormones (Non PIG)

questions.text: The serum calcium level is regulated by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
1. In addition to having significant impacts on bone formation and bone resorption, vitamin D has a strong influence on increasing calcium absorption from the intestinal tract.

The exchange between extracellular fluid and bone, intestinal reabsorption, and renal excretion are all regulated by parathyroid hormone.

deficiency of PTH leads to hypocalcemia, which frequently results in tetany. excess of PTH  results in the fast release of calcium salts from the bones and hypercalcemia in the extracellular fluid.

The thyroid gland's peptide hormone, calcitonin, tends to lower plasma levels of calcium. In general, it has the opposite effects of PTH.

To summarise remember the story of calcium metabolism as follows 

Whenever there is Calcium and Phosphate in blood, it will deposit in bone in form of Ca appatite. Vit D causes increased absorption of Ca and Phosphate from intestine and thereby deposits it in Bones. The prime role of Calcitonin is preventing the Ca from bone to reach the blood, or making it stay put in bones. 
Parathormone doesn’t care about anything else but Calcium, it increases Ca absorption via Vit D from GIT, but as vit D increases Phosphate absorption also, PTH causes excretion of Phosphate via urine to prevent the calcium from going into bone as Calcium appatite.

choices.text: Integration of multiple signalling pathways within the cell
They transmit signals from surface receptors and activate internal signalling pathway

questions.text: Which amongst these is not a function of secondary messenger/molecules?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:

2. Direct activation of DNA duplication

Secondary messengers do not directly activate DNA duplication. Their primary role is to relay and amplify signals received by cell surface receptors, thereby regulating various cellular processes, including metabolism, gene expression, and cell growth. However, they do not directly trigger DNA duplication (which involves the activation of specific regulatory pathways and proteins).

Here’s why the other options are correct for secondary messengers:

  1. Regulation of cellular processes (e.g., metabolism): Secondary messengers play a key role in regulating various cellular functions, including metabolism, by influencing enzymes, proteins, and other molecules within the cell.

  2. Integration of multiple signaling pathways within the cell: Secondary messengers help coordinate signals from different pathways, integrating them to generate a unified cellular response.

  3. They transmit signals from surface receptors and activate internal signaling pathways: This is one of the primary roles of secondary messengers. They act as intermediaries between surface receptors and the intracellular machinery that executes the cellular response.

    Reference -Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition • Page no: 60

questions.text: Thyroid hormone acts via which among the following receptor?
questions.solution:
Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are lipophilic hormones that easily cross the cell membrane. Their main site of action is the nucleus, where T3 (the active form) binds to the thyroid hormone receptor (a type of nuclear receptor, part of the steroid–thyroid hormone receptor superfamily).

  • The receptor is usually bound to DNA at thyroid hormone response elements (TREs).

  • In the absence of hormone, the receptor represses transcription.

  • When T3 binds, it activates transcription of specific genes, leading to protein synthesis and metabolic effects.



    Other options:

  • Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase: Typical for insulin and growth factors, not thyroid hormone.

  • G protein coupled receptor (GPCR): Used by peptide hormones like ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, not thyroid hormone.

  • Cytoplasmic receptor: Seen in steroid hormones like cortisol (receptor in cytoplasm → then migrates to nucleus), but thyroid hormone receptor is already nuclear.


Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Pages 47, 792.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for galactokinesis?
questions.solution:

  1. Myoepithelial contraction causing milk ejection
  2. large doses have an ADH-like effect (reduces urine output)
  3. contraction of the uterus


Other options:

  • Progesterone: Prepares breast tissue during pregnancy but does not cause milk ejection.

  • Prolactin: Responsible for galactopoiesis (milk production/maintenance), not galactokinesis.

  • Vasopressin (ADH): Regulates water balance, no role in lactation.

questions.text: A study was conducted on a group of people to study the factors that increase and inhibit the secretion of insulin. Which of the following factors inhibit its secretion?
questions.solution:
While cholinergic, gastric inhibitory polypeptide, and glucagon enhance insulin production, epinephrine decreases it. The adrenergic system, which controls insulin release through the effects of epinephrine and norepinephrine in response to glucose shortage, is a major inhibitor of insulin secretion.

When blood glucose levels rise, pancreatic beta cells secrete insulin. It makes it easier for the liver to absorb, store, and use glucose. Elevated blood glucose causes glucose to be stored as glycogen in the liver very fast. Furthermore, extra glucose is converted into fatty acids. When blood glucose levels fall, the body secretes less insulin and the enzyme phosphorylase is activated, which breaks down glycogen and releases glucose that has been stored in the body into the bloodstream.



Reference
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition - Page no: 974-976, 979-980, 983

questions.text: Which of the following cells is involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity?
questions.solution:
The start and management of osteoclastic activity are mediated by osteoblasts.

The production of macrophage colonystimulating factor (M-CSF) and receptor activator for nuclear factor KB ligand (RANKL) by osteoblasts is required for the development of mature osteoclasts and, consequently, for osteoclastic activity.

Only osteoblasts have specific parathormone receptors; osteoclasts do not have these receptors.

Osteoblasts secrete RANKL (Receptor Activator of Nuclear factor Kappa-B Ligand), which binds to RANK receptors on osteoclast precursors, stimulating their differentiation and activation.

They also produce osteoprotegerin (OPG), a decoy receptor that inhibits RANKL, thereby regulating osteoclast formation.

Thus, osteoblasts play the key regulatory role in initiating and modulating osteoclastic activity.



Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical physiology 13th edition page no 1006

questions.text: ACTH secretion is inhibited by___
questions.solution:
ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone) secretion from the anterior pituitary is regulated by a negative feedback loop involving glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol.

  • Glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) inhibit both:

    • Hypothalamic CRH (Corticotropin-releasing hormone) secretion

    • Pituitary ACTH secretion

This ensures homeostasis of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.

Other options:

  • Epinephrine: Has no direct effect on ACTH inhibition.

  • CRH: Stimulates ACTH secretion.

  • Aldosterone: Does not regulate ACTH via feedback; it is mainly regulated by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).



Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical physiology 13th edition page no 977

questions.text: In fetus, the insulin secretion begins by ___(months)

  • Although pancreatic islets start forming earlier (around 10 weeks), they begin functional insulin secretion only after 20 weeks.

  • Insulin does not cross the placenta, so the fetus produces its own.

    Key Timeline for Fetal Endocrine Development:

Milestone Time
Islets of Langerhans appear ~10 weeks
Insulin secretion begins ~20 weeks
Functional insulin response ~28 weeks

questions.text: How long is thyroxine stored in thyroid follicles?
questions.solution:
Thyroid hormones (primarily thyroxine, T‚ÇÑ) are stored in the colloid of thyroid follicles as part of thyroglobulin. Unlike most endocrine glands, the thyroid stores large quantities of its hormone — this storage can last for 2–3 months under normal conditions.

  • This means that even if thyroid hormone synthesis stops, the body can maintain near-normal levels for several weeks to months because of this reservoir.

    How is T‚ÇÑ stored?

  • Iodide is taken up by the follicular cells and oxidized.

  • Tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin are iodinated to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT).

  • These residues combine:

    • DIT + DIT → T‚ÇÑ

    • MIT + DIT → T‚ÇÉ

  • T‚ÇÑ and T‚ÇÉ remain bound to thyroglobulin in the colloid — this is the stored form

  • Thyroid hormone synthesis is a slow process that involves iodide trapping, oxidation, organification, and coupling — all of which take time.


Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical physiology 13th edition page no 953

questions.text: Identify the hormone that will be most affected after the change in sex hormone binding globulin.
questions.solution:
Sex hormone binding  globulin has a strong affinity for binding sex hormones as follows: DHT>Testosterone>Estrone/estradiol.

Variations in SHBG have a significant impact on the levels of androgens because of the increased affinity of SHBG for DHT and Testosterone compared to Estrone.


Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/biochemistry-genetics-and-molecular-biology/sex-hormone-binding-globulin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the blood-testis barrier?
questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier, formed by Sertoli cells, develops during puberty and is essential for protecting germ cells from the immune system. It is not fully established before primary spermatogenesis begins.

The adjacent Sertoli cells are bound together by a unique Sertoli cell- to-Sertoli cell junctional complex at the basolateral part of the cell, forming a blood-testis barrier. This complex is composed of a tight junction in the adjacent membranes, a flattened cisterna of sER lying parallel to the plasma membrane in the region of the junction in each cell and actin filament bundles that are hexagonally packed and interposed between the sER cisternae and the plasma membranes.Germ cells are not necessary for blood testis barrier.

 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 411,412

questions.text: Where is the blood-testis barrier located?
questions.solution:
Blood testis barrier is located between sertoli and sertoli cells.

Sertoli cells are connected by tight junctions, the body's strongest intercellular barriers. This configuration forms the blood testes barrier. The blood testes barrier protects developing sperms from immune attack and blood borne noxious agents.

The tight junctions forms the major barriers in our body like the blood brain barrier, the blood testes barrier etc.
Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 411,412

Occurs after the disappearance of cervical mucus thickening

questions.text: Pick the option that is correct with regards to the time of ovulation.
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options - only option (3) is correct. 

FSH and LH are both in charge of the follicular phase, thus controlling follicular ripening with a surge of LH leading to ovulation. These two hormones result in the maturation of the follicle.

Option 1 - Ovulation occurs after LH Surge (not before as given in option 1)

Option 2 - It is associated with a rise in basal body temperature (it doesn't occur after the rise)

Option 4 - Ovulation tends to occur during the period of highest cervical mucus thickening or one day after of this type of cervical secretion (but not after its disappearance)

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 392,393

questions.text: Where does meiosis take place in the human cell?
questions.solution:
The meiosis is a type of cell division that takes place only in the reproductive organs to produce haploid gametes. Gametogenesis in males, known as spermatogenesis, begins with primordial germ cells, or PCs, that remain dormant until puberty in the seminiferous tubules of the testes. At this point, the seminiferous tubules mature and the PCs undergo a series of mitotic divisions to form spermatogonia. These spermatogonia then produce primary spermatocytes, and each of these primary spermatocytes will undergo Meiosis I and Meiosis II to form four spermatids. The result of this meiotic process is the production of haploid gametes which can then be used for sexual reproduction.

In adult ovaries meiosis 1 is completed and secondary oocysts are formed which stay in metaphase 2 after ovulation. Hence option 2 is the correct option. 

 

References - Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no390

questions.solution:

Estrogen causes the mother's breasts to enlarge and the breast ductal system to grow.

The physical growth of the breasts during pregnancy depends on the hormones estrogen and progesterone, both of which have the unique effect of inhibiting milk secretion.

Milk production and mammary gland development are encouraged by prolactin.

questions.text:
Arrange the following components in spermatogenesis from adluminal to luminal 
(A) Myoepithelial cells 
(B) Spermatogonia 
(C) Primary spermatocyte 
(D) Spermatid 
(E) Secondary spermatocyte
questions.solution:
The correct arrangement of the components in spermatogenesis from adluminal to luminal  is as follows:

(A) Myoepithelial cells - These cells are located near the basal lamina and have contractile properties that help in the movement of spermatozoa.

(B) Spermatogonia - These are the germ cells that reside close to the basal lamina and undergo mitotic division to maintain the germ cell population.

(C) Primary spermatocyte - These cells are formed through the differentiation of spermatogonia 

(E) Secondary spermatocytes - These are the result of the meiotic division of primary spermatocytes 

(D) Spermatid - These cells are formed through the differentiation of secondary spermatocytes 

Therefore, the correct arrangement from adluminal to luminal is Myoepithelial cells (A) - Spermatogonia (B) - Primary spermatocyte (C) - Secondary spermatocyte (E) - Spermatid (D).





Reference: Langman's Medical Embryology, 14th edition, Page no 29-31.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is false about male sexual development?
1. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body.
2. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characteristics and external genitalia.
3. At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent.
4. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits the Mullerian duct.
questions.solution:
The embryo remains bipotent until seven weeks of gestation, not eight. By the seventh week, the embryo contains both male and female primordial genital ducts. In a female fetus, the Müllerian duct develops into the uterine tubes and uterus. In a male fetus, the Wolffian duct system on each side forms the epididymis and vas deferens.

Testosterone, produced by the Leydig cells of the fetal testes, and Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS), secreted by the Sertoli cells, play crucial roles. MIS, an amino acid in the transforming growth factor B (TGF-B) family, induces apoptosis in the Müllerian ducts on the side of its secretion.

Dihydrotestosterone, a derivative of testosterone, is responsible for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sex characteristics. Testosterone also drives the formation of the vas deferens, epididymis, and other structures from the Wolffian ducts.

 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 387,388 .

questions.text: A mother complains of cramps in her breasts while breastfeeding her child. Which hormone is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The myoepithelial contraction that causes the ejection of milk is aided by oxytocin. The breast tissue may cramp as a result of this.

Among oxytocin's functions are:

* Myoepithelial contraction causing milk ejection

* High doses have an ADH-like effect (reduces urine output)

* Contractions in the uterus

Remember, 
Hormones and Their Effects on the Breast
Hormone Source Effect on Breast
Estrogen Ovary (Granulosa cells), Placenta Stimulates ductal system growth (branching of ducts)
Progesterone Ovary (Corpus luteum), Placenta Stimulates lobuloalveolar development
Prolactin Anterior pituitary Stimulates milk synthesis (lactogenesis)
Oxytocin Posterior pituitary Triggers milk ejection (let-down reflex) via myoepithelial cell contraction
Human Placental Lactogen (hPL) Placenta Supports breast development during pregnancy
Cortisol Adrenal cortex Permissive role in milk production
Insulin Pancreas Supports breast tissue metabolism and milk production


Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th edition- page no 673

questions.text: Inhibin B is secreted by____
questions.solution:
• Inhibin B is secreted by the granulosa cells of the developing ovarian follicles, especially during the early to mid-follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.

  • Its primary role is to inhibit FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary by negative feedback.

    Other options: 

  • Surface epithelium: does not produce inhibin.

  • Stroma: involved in steroidogenesis but not the main source of inhibin.

  • Corpus luteum: secretes inhibin A, not inhibin B.

    Functions of Inhibin B:
     

    Function Description
    Negative feedback on FSH Inhibin B primarily inhibits follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion from the anterior pituitary.
    Follicular regulation Helps in selection of the dominant follicle by reducing FSH and thus inhibiting growth of other follicles.
    Marker of ovarian reserve Inhibin B levels decline with age and reduced ovarian reserve, making it a useful clinical marker for fertility assessment.


Reference:Medical physiology 2e updated edition page no 2173
